description: Windows 7 is still a viable option out in the IT world and is one of the most commonly used desktop operating systems today. This series covers routine administrative tasks that any Desktop Support Technician or Help Desk Technician would be expected to handle on a regular basis including installation and deployment, managing and maintaining, and operational issues one may encounter supporting Windows 7 as an enterprise level technician.

subtitle: Configuring and maintaining Windows 7

00:09:34.010 --> 00:09:35.310
Does that happen?

203
00:09:35.310 --> 00:09:36.280
You better believe it.

204
00:09:36.280 --> 00:09:40.720
It absolutely happens where somebody says,
I wonder if this cable here is-

205
00:09:40.720 --> 00:09:41.770
>> We work with Mike Rodder [LAUGH]

206
00:09:41.770 --> 00:09:42.810
>> Yes that's true.

207
00:09:42.810 --> 00:09:43.850
>> We know how that goes.

208
00:09:43.850 --> 00:09:47.100
>> And so here's an issue that you
can face where it gets stopped by us.

209
00:09:47.100 --> 00:09:49.130
Check your physical connections first.

210
00:09:49.130 --> 00:09:51.400
Network issues do happen, right?

211
00:09:51.400 --> 00:09:53.303
The very fact is somebody
can actually do that.

212
00:09:53.303 --> 00:09:56.570
So don't overlook just
regular network issues.

213
00:09:56.570 --> 00:09:57.950
So when you see it stalled like this,

00:09:57.950 --> 00:10:00.130
that's another thing that
you can end up seeing.

215
00:10:01.400 --> 00:10:03.840
The other thing that you
also will experience too.

216
00:10:03.840 --> 00:10:06.670
And I'm leaving it as is, cuz right now
it's probably saying I need to try and

00:10:06.670 --> 00:10:08.985
connect that one, see if I can
connect back and we'll start again.

218
00:10:08.985 --> 00:10:10.830
It'll probably fail at this point.

219
00:10:10.830 --> 00:10:11.620
>> [LAUGH]
>> But, and

00:10:11.620 --> 00:10:14.310
if it starts back then
you're actually up and good.

221
00:10:14.310 --> 00:10:16.170
But one of the weird things
that ends up happening.

222
00:10:16.170 --> 00:10:18.840
And Daniel, you've probably
experienced this before too.

223
00:10:18.840 --> 00:10:20.160
We've had these computers.

224
00:10:20.160 --> 00:10:21.990
All identical computers.

00:10:21.990 --> 00:10:27.270

226
00:10:27.270 --> 00:10:28.850

227
00:10:28.850 --> 00:10:30.790

00:10:30.790 --> 00:10:32.910
They were started exactly

229
00:10:32.910 --> 00:10:36.240
They connect to the same

230
00:10:36.240 --> 00:10:38.930
Those two computers absolutely failed.

00:10:38.930 --> 00:10:40.900
Usually that does indicate
that there is a issue.

232
00:10:40.900 --> 00:10:41.500
Where?

233

At those local computers that you
also need to troubleshoot too.

00:10:46.170 --> 00:10:49.310
The easiest way to troubleshoot that

00:10:49.310 --> 00:10:51.470

00:10:51.470 --> 00:10:52.340
If they still fail,

00:10:52.340 --> 00:10:54.570
then you know the issue is
actually with those two computers,

238
00:10:54.570 --> 00:10:56.350
cuz the other 14 were actually successful.

239
00:10:56.350 --> 00:10:57.900
Notice it actually did pick up.

240
00:10:57.900 --> 00:11:00.300
So, even though it stalled,
and it actually is good,

00:11:00.300 --> 00:11:03.120
cuz that means it can do something,
like that.

242
00:11:03.120 --> 00:11:07.044
Now, the good thing is with the deployment
services, when you have a lot of computers

00:11:07.044 --> 00:11:09.514

00:11:09.514 --> 00:11:13.660

actually say, look, I'm gonna wait for

00:11:13.660 --> 00:11:16.442
16 computers to connect
before I send out the image.

246
00:11:16.442 --> 00:11:18.630

to send it out one time.

247
00:11:18.630 --> 00:11:21.210
If not, if you go, I don't worry
about the multicast group and

248
00:11:21.210 --> 00:11:23.780
the administrator didn't
actually set that up.

249
00:11:23.780 --> 00:11:26.770
Well you're actually connecting
16 different computers and

250
00:11:26.770 --> 00:11:27.610
it's a 25 gig drive.

251
00:11:27.610 --> 00:11:30.835
It's sending out 25
gigs 16 times in a row.

252
00:11:30.835 --> 00:11:34.317
[CROSSTALK] That's
a pretty hefty saturation.

253
00:11:34.317 --> 00:11:34.990
>> Yeah.

254
00:11:34.990 --> 00:11:38.080
>> So you will also experience slow
downs with things like that as well.

255
00:11:38.080 --> 00:11:41.690
So, those are some of the other deployment
issues you do have to worry about.

256
00:11:41.690 --> 00:11:45.460
So, if you go all right I want to do this,
I want this to connect.

257
00:11:45.460 --> 00:11:48.660
First thing of course, you need
a computer that will support Pixie Boot.

258
00:11:48.660 --> 00:11:51.330
So if your network adapter

00:11:51.330 --> 00:11:54.165
well deployment services is not

260
00:11:54.165 --> 00:11:56.621
>> [LAUGH]
>> What you have now is of course gonna be

261
00:11:56.621 --> 00:11:59.956
your Windows PE disk [LAUGH]
that you will actually be using.

262
00:11:59.956 --> 00:12:02.284
And then hopefully being able
to connect to a network share.

263
00:12:02.284 --> 00:12:05.728
And start your deployment from that point,
too, connecting,

264
00:12:05.728 --> 00:12:07.782
of course, to the deployment share.

265
00:12:07.782 --> 00:12:08.685
And here's another one.

266
00:12:08.685 --> 00:12:15.371
Good thing is, if it's set up correctly,
like what mine is, yeah, I set it up.

267
00:12:15.371 --> 00:12:16.573
But if it's set up correctly,

268
00:12:16.573 --> 00:12:18.709
it should automatically do
exactly what I showed you.

269
00:12:18.709 --> 00:12:19.963
Select the network boot.

270
00:12:19.963 --> 00:12:22.735
It finds that deployment server,
it should connect in,

271
00:12:22.735 --> 00:12:24.690
you shouldn't have very many issues.

272
00:12:24.690 --> 00:12:26.371
It's made to be fairly easy.

273
00:12:26.371 --> 00:12:29.597
So your key here is the choice
that you have to make.

274
00:12:29.597 --> 00:12:33.335
If the names aren't actually,
exactly very descriptive.

275
00:12:33.335 --> 00:12:34.979
You have to do a little
bit more research and

276
00:12:34.979 --> 00:12:36.540
figure out which one you actually need.

277
00:12:36.540 --> 00:12:38.164
Verify it is the information
that you need.

278
00:12:38.164 --> 00:12:41.655
It's always one of those weird things when
you deploy the wrong image to the wrong

279
00:12:41.655 --> 00:12:44.597
machine, because they're hardware
independent today, right?

280
00:12:44.597 --> 00:12:48.347
You can actually take an image that
doesn't even belong to the same computer

281
00:12:48.347 --> 00:12:51.057
grouping, or
the same type of computer and deploy it.

282
00:12:51.057 --> 00:12:53.060
And then go,
I don't know why it looks this way.

283
00:12:53.060 --> 00:12:55.580
Well it's more than likely
you picked that wrong image.

284
00:12:55.580 --> 00:12:58.870
And you see right here, on my screen
it's actually already finished,

285
00:12:58.870 --> 00:12:59.440
and there it goes.

286
00:12:59.440 --> 00:13:02.340
It's actually rebooting at this
point to finish out the rest of that

00:13:02.340 --> 00:13:03.880
installation for us.

288
00:13:03.880 --> 00:13:06.330
So deployment can be very
quick at this point, too.

289
00:13:07.740 --> 00:13:09.830
This time I'm not actually
going to hit my network boot.

290
00:13:09.830 --> 00:13:11.340
So I don't actually do anything.

291
00:13:11.340 --> 00:13:12.620
And then it's gonna go on through, and

292
00:13:12.620 --> 00:13:15.230
it should start the rest of
the process of the installation.

293
00:13:15.230 --> 00:13:16.660
And we should be fine.

294
00:13:16.660 --> 00:13:18.920
But you do have to worry about
those simple, common things.

295
00:13:18.920 --> 00:13:20.298
The network issues.

296
00:13:20.298 --> 00:13:24.580
Then the PXI booting, make sure that
we're picking the right image out.

297
00:13:24.580 --> 00:13:26.940
You should be fine and ready to go.

298
00:13:26.940 --> 00:13:27.620
>> Yeah, I like that.

299
00:13:27.620 --> 00:13:29.050
Right.
It's very nice to be able to say,

00:13:29.050 --> 00:13:31.520

00:13:31.520 --> 00:13:34.990
I'm gonna deploy this out, I'm just

00:13:34.990 --> 00:13:36.100
And then Ronnie said yeah,

you gotta make sure that that

But if you're buying 20 new computers,

00:13:46.047 --> 00:13:49.214
You just tell that manufacturer,
hey these things have got to support PXI,

307
00:13:49.214 --> 00:13:51.354
because I'm gonna be doing
deployment services.

00:13:51.354 --> 00:13:53.559
Cuz I want to make my
life a little bit easier.

00:13:53.559 --> 00:13:57.366
And use that nice,

00:13:57.366 --> 00:14:00.766
I say I'm gonna deploy it once, goes out

00:14:04.140 --> 00:14:06.500

00:14:06.500 --> 00:14:10.670

00:14:10.670 --> 00:14:15.830
to actually find out more about that,

00:14:19.490 --> 00:14:23.423
And you'll actually find out a lot more

Don't get me wrong, it's something that

not gonna be the ones that actually

00:14:29.486 --> 00:14:34.240
are getting the images, storing them and

00:14:34.240 --> 00:14:36.390
>> But we do need to make
sure that they're there.

The only other issue that I can think of,

00:14:37.440 --> 00:14:40.980
I was just thinking about this at the very
end here is that when you do finish

00:14:46.080 --> 00:14:47.885

00:14:47.885 --> 00:14:50.903

If it didn't, it more than likely means

00:14:55.830 --> 00:14:58.011
And this is where you would

00:14:58.011 --> 00:15:02.000
If the answer file didn't apply when you

00:15:02.000 --> 00:15:06.760
Well, then you do know that hey, at some
point here something else has to be done.

00:15:06.760 --> 00:15:09.139
And you may not have that

00:15:09.139 --> 00:15:11.809
So you just escalate it and

00:15:11.809 --> 00:15:15.238
And say, look all of my computers I just

00:15:15.238 --> 00:15:18.850
actually or, I didn't get this,
I didn't get this, I didn't get this.

00:15:18.850 --> 00:15:20.290
They can take a look at it.

00:15:20.290 --> 00:15:22.910
Mine, probably is deploying, but

00:15:22.910 --> 00:15:24.240
So it's going to take
a little bit of time.

>> So, just walk through that

00:15:26.330 --> 00:15:28.290

You've deployed Windows out
using a network that is a.

That's the way to do it nowadays,

00:15:43.450 --> 00:15:45.321

00:15:45.984 --> 00:15:46.565

00:15:49.076 --> 00:15:50.180

00:00:21.010 --> 00:00:24.860
And take a look at some Windows 7,

00:00:24.860 --> 00:00:26.230

00:00:41.735 --> 00:00:46.315

work together and it can be pretty

00:00:46.315 --> 00:00:50.115

it so we're gonna simplify it for you.

16
00:00:50.115 --> 00:00:53.725

17
00:00:53.725 --> 00:00:58.700
So let's start with working with our

00:00:58.700 --> 00:01:03.110
You know when we start taking a look
at implementing some type of policy,

you may be like I was the first
time I heard it about it,

00:01:05.810 --> 00:01:09.050
"What in the world to I actually
need something like this

00:01:09.050 --> 00:01:13.320
if I'm the only one on this machine and
it's doing what I need to Mike,

22
00:01:13.320 --> 00:01:17.040
is there a reason for me to actually
mess around with any of those settings?

23
00:01:17.040 --> 00:01:18.140
>> There's really not.

24
00:01:18.140 --> 00:01:20.180
And let's go back one step and

25
00:01:20.180 --> 00:01:24.100
make sure we understand what we mean
when we say a policy because we know if

26
00:01:24.100 --> 00:01:27.250
you're using a Windows operating system,
and Windows 7 no different,

27
00:01:27.250 --> 00:01:30.740
that there are literally thousands
of settings that I can configure.

28
00:01:30.740 --> 00:01:34.790
In my operating system, from very simple
things like how long it is before my

00:01:34.790 --> 00:01:39.240
screen saver kicks in, to much more
complex things like which programs

00:01:39.240 --> 00:01:43.930
are allowed to run, preventing access

31
00:01:43.930 --> 00:01:47.860
So, I can go in to my machine and

00:01:47.860 --> 00:01:49.110
Through the gooey.

00:01:49.110 --> 00:01:54.060
Or I could dive into the registry and
I could make some changes there, but

00:01:54.060 --> 00:01:59.250
if I want to try to have it
affect more than one person, or

35
00:01:59.250 --> 00:02:02.390
if I want to do this in
a more streamlined fashion,

00:02:02.390 --> 00:02:04.880
that's really when that local

00:02:04.880 --> 00:02:09.140
Because every Windows

00:02:09.140 --> 00:02:13.690

00:02:13.690 --> 00:02:14.680
everyone that logs on.

00:02:14.680 --> 00:02:17.170
So, to get back to your question Ronnie,

00:02:17.170 --> 00:02:21.200
Well if you're the only user on that

00:02:21.200 --> 00:02:22.110
you could do it either way.

00:02:22.110 --> 00:02:23.320
Either way would work just fine.

44
00:02:23.320 --> 00:02:26.960
Do I go into my GUI and configure
the settings like my screen saver timeout?

45
00:02:26.960 --> 00:02:27.560
Sure.

46
00:02:27.560 --> 00:02:31.130
Do I go into my local policy and

00:02:31.130 --> 00:02:33.970
That would work just as fine as well.

48
00:02:33.970 --> 00:02:36.840
But the difference is, or
when you wanna use that policy,

00:02:36.840 --> 00:02:39.000
is when you might have More than one user.

50
00:02:39.000 --> 00:02:40.490
What if you have shared computers?

51
00:02:40.490 --> 00:02:43.940
What if people float between machines?

52
00:02:43.940 --> 00:02:47.100
That's when these local
policies can come into effect.

53
00:02:47.100 --> 00:02:50.080
>> It really is a beneficial process for

54
00:02:50.080 --> 00:02:53.990
us to actually be able to implement this
type of policy, because if we do have

55
00:02:53.990 --> 00:02:56.760
multiple people working on that machine
>> and

56
00:02:56.760 --> 00:02:59.060
you go I just bought that machine and
everybody works off of it.

57
00:02:59.060 --> 00:03:02.440
That's perfectly fine, but
remember when people end up and

00:03:02.440 --> 00:03:07.290
you create different accounts for
them and they log in, if you go I

00:03:07.290 --> 00:03:09.980
want to make it administrator and do that
>> That means

60
00:03:09.980 --> 00:03:13.250
any changes that they make can

00:03:13.250 --> 00:03:15.580
So you may not have it like

00:03:15.580 --> 00:03:19.020
even though I've created accounts for
my wife, and for my daughter, and for

63
00:03:19.020 --> 00:03:23.200
myself on our computer so that we keep all
of our settings differently, it doesn't

00:03:23.200 --> 00:03:27.170
matter because my wife just leaves me
logged on all the time, and so when I come

00:03:27.170 --> 00:03:31.780
home I never know what's going to be on my
desktop at times, whether the background's

66
00:03:31.780 --> 00:03:35.690
going to change Whether there's actually
going to be some configuration, whether or

67
00:03:35.690 --> 00:03:39.350
not they've added in some
application that's on the computer.

68
00:03:39.350 --> 00:03:41.930
You name it, there's so
many different changes and I come back and

69
00:03:41.930 --> 00:03:43.640
it's not even the same computer.

70
00:03:43.640 --> 00:03:44.690
There's a lot of times when I go,

71
00:03:44.690 --> 00:03:48.010
I don't even know what computer
I'm sitting on anymore.

72
00:03:48.010 --> 00:03:50.590
So policies can help us,

There will be common ones that you're

We can always take one

4

5
00:00:18.120 --> 00:00:19.750
>> I am doing fine today.

6

It's another wonderful day here in Florida

10

Today we've got a good show continuing on

12
00:00:35.440 --> 00:00:38.350
We're going to be taking a look at the,
where are we going?

13
00:00:38.350 --> 00:00:41.620
The task manager and the resource monitor.

14
00:00:41.620 --> 00:00:44.480
Remember it's all about trying to make
sure that these Windows 7 machines

15
00:00:44.480 --> 00:00:48.650
are running well,
that their performance is acceptable,

16
00:00:48.650 --> 00:00:51.280
that they're not crashing all the time,

00:00:51.280 --> 00:00:55.000
And so Microsoft gives us a bunch

To do that, to keep an eye on our system.

To find out what the heck is causing

slow or what's choking the system of
taking up all those resources and

00:01:05.640 --> 00:01:08.380

00:01:08.380 --> 00:01:11.350
>> Yes, well when we start taking
a look at what we're talking about,

00:01:11.350 --> 00:01:15.910
right, we as technicians,
as people supporting Windows 7,

00:01:15.910 --> 00:01:19.990
is very easy to just take
someone's word and say, Okay,

25
00:01:19.990 --> 00:01:25.790
your machine's running slow, and you don't
realize that mental perception at times,

26
00:01:25.790 --> 00:01:27.350
and whether or
not the machine's running slow.

27

a few of those.

00:01:40.630 --> 00:01:43.880
>> You and I have both have had a few

the way that you think it is.

35
00:01:47.350 --> 00:01:49.220
But, is there a way to verify,

36
00:01:49.220 --> 00:01:52.530
is there a way that we can actually
take the machine that we're given.

37
00:01:52.530 --> 00:01:57.330
Running Windows 7 and
take a look at the performance itself and

38
00:01:57.330 --> 00:02:00.200
verify whether everything's
actually working or not.

39

When it comes down to the performance
of an individual PC or

40
00:02:03.990 --> 00:02:05.210
even just a computer server,

41
00:02:05.210 --> 00:02:09.450
whatever it is, normally we're looking at
four different aspects of that computer.

42
00:02:09.450 --> 00:02:11.639
These are the big four,
don't get me wrong,

43
00:02:11.639 --> 00:02:15.558
there's can be many things that actually
hinder performance on the computer but

44
00:02:15.558 --> 00:02:19.646
when it comes down to it, it's normally
the CPU okay, the RAM, the hard drive, and

45
00:02:19.646 --> 00:02:21.490
even the network connection.

46
00:02:21.490 --> 00:02:23.180
Now are there other things yes, but

47
00:02:23.180 --> 00:02:27.575
those are usually the four big ones
that we're actually concerned about.

48
00:02:27.575 --> 00:02:28.565
Peg on any one of them.

49
00:02:28.565 --> 00:02:32.195
Now once you get the utilization
on one of those resources,

50
00:02:32.195 --> 00:02:35.575
higher than any of the other ones, that
generally actually starts to tell you that

51
00:02:35.575 --> 00:02:39.865
there may be a performance issue there
that may actually only be overcome by

52
00:02:39.865 --> 00:02:45.040
either adding in additional something or
by changing out the component or even

53
00:02:45.040 --> 00:02:48.830
that the systems actually so old that you

54
00:02:48.830 --> 00:02:50.600
So that's what we actually
want to take a look at and

55
00:02:50.600 --> 00:02:51.930
make sure that you understand that.

56
00:02:51.930 --> 00:02:55.350
>> Like a lot of my machines,
they're just too old, beyond all hope so.

00:02:55.350 --> 00:02:57.540

>> All right, so

00:03:35.590 --> 00:03:38.310
you should experiment with

Right?

00:18:11.880 --> 00:18:15.290
I can also add,
remove some columns from here.

363
00:18:15.290 --> 00:18:20.920
I can do bytes sent and bytes received,
let's see if I can turn those guys on,

364
00:18:20.920 --> 00:18:26.420
and bytes received, I'll make this
a little bit wider and where'd they go?

365
00:18:26.420 --> 00:18:29.378
>> Yeah, you're not gonna see much
utilization in this one because you

366
00:18:29.378 --> 00:18:31.472
actually have a gigabyte
network adapter on it.

367
00:18:31.472 --> 00:18:36.003
And unless you actually start screaming
something from your computer regularly

368
00:18:36.003 --> 00:18:40.250
You're probably not gonna see that
utilization rate as you go up.

369
00:18:40.250 --> 00:18:43.110
This has actually been around since
the days that we were actually on

370
00:18:43.110 --> 00:18:45.270
all a single bus network.

371
00:18:45.270 --> 00:18:47.700
In other words,
we were actually using hubs.

372
00:18:47.700 --> 00:18:52.151
And the utilization behind that is because
before I send a print job or actually sent

373
00:18:52.151 --> 00:18:56.618
a file out there, I needed to actually see
what the utilization was on the network.

374
00:18:56.618 --> 00:19:00.282
Cuz if I sent it out where there was
high utilization, it could get there,

375
00:19:00.282 --> 00:19:04.620
but it could get there in a long time,
so I might actually wait to do that.

376
00:19:04.620 --> 00:19:08.680
In this one it does actually help me to
monitor what goes in and out of my system,

377
00:19:08.680 --> 00:19:13.430
But as far as the real usage of it that's
gonna help you pinpoint something,

378
00:19:13.430 --> 00:19:15.260
it's probably not gonna
help you pinpoint a lot.

379
00:19:15.260 --> 00:19:20.740
The only time I've ever actually seen it
effectively work on my computer is when we

380
00:19:20.740 --> 00:19:25.470
were actually running the same streaming
software that Mike's running, but we were

381
00:19:25.470 --> 00:19:29.670
not sure exactly how to run it so we used
to run it over the wireless connection.

382
00:19:29.670 --> 00:19:32.930
So I had that actually turned up and
I saw it on the wireless that

383
00:19:32.930 --> 00:19:37.430
on the wireless connection what Mike's
output's actually is about 45 megabits.

384
00:19:37.430 --> 00:19:39.830
Well, our wireless is only 54 megabits.

385
00:19:39.830 --> 00:19:42.600
And so that's when we realize that
that was where some of the bottleneck

386
00:19:42.600 --> 00:19:43.880
issues where happening.

387
00:19:43.880 --> 00:19:46.461
Once we actually said, all right,
we're gonna just wire in,

388
00:19:46.461 --> 00:19:50.016
we're not gonna actually just go wireless,
we actually stopped experiencing a lot of

389
00:19:50.016 --> 00:19:53.210
the dropout problems that we were
having in displaying our monitors.

390
00:19:53.210 --> 00:19:57.260
So it was helpful,
one time as far as I know.

391
00:19:57.260 --> 00:19:59.460
I'm not saying you can't use it for
any other reason but, for

392
00:19:59.460 --> 00:20:01.060
me, that was the one time.

393
00:20:01.060 --> 00:20:03.240
I was like in ten years there it is.

394
00:20:03.240 --> 00:20:05.010
That's the reason why have it.

395
00:20:05.010 --> 00:20:09.780
>> I'll tell you why I've used it
before and you've ever been on the web,

396
00:20:09.780 --> 00:20:13.260
you're trying to download something, and
the progress bar is just not moving.

397
00:20:13.260 --> 00:20:14.120
It's just sitting there.

398
00:20:14.120 --> 00:20:15.770
So it's like, come on.

399
00:20:15.770 --> 00:20:18.170
And I can come in here and
I can see well look,

400
00:20:18.170 --> 00:20:20.020
there's no network traffic going on,
right?

401
00:20:20.020 --> 00:20:22.890
So I know that it's not my
network bottlenecking everything.

402
00:20:22.890 --> 00:20:25.740
It's probably some reason the website
is taking some time getting

403
00:20:25.740 --> 00:20:26.930
ready to send me that files.

404
00:20:26.930 --> 00:20:29.550
So, maybe I'll be use it for
something like that as well.

405
00:20:29.550 --> 00:20:31.945
And then the last tab is
simply the users tab.

406
00:20:31.945 --> 00:20:32.880
>> [LAUGH]
>> And this is gonna

407
00:20:32.880 --> 00:20:36.420
show me all the different users
that are currently connected to,

408
00:20:36.420 --> 00:20:40.830
either remotely or
interactively with this machine.

409
00:20:40.830 --> 00:20:44.920
And from here,
I can do a couple of cool things.

410
00:20:44.920 --> 00:20:48.371
I can send them a message as well
as disconnect or log them off.

411
00:20:48.371 --> 00:20:52.381
Right now I'm logged on as administrator,
I can see my status as active and

412
00:20:52.381 --> 00:20:54.710
I've got a console session running.

413
00:20:54.710 --> 00:20:58.550
Meaning I'm local,
I'm interactive with this machine,

414
00:20:58.550 --> 00:21:02.270
if I had a somebody
remoted into this machine.

415
00:21:02.270 --> 00:21:03.350
We would see that there as well.

416
00:21:03.350 --> 00:21:07.260
Remember with a client operating systems,
you can't really have somebody remoted in

417
00:21:07.260 --> 00:21:10.850
as well as logged on interactively so
I couldn't show you that here.

418
00:21:10.850 --> 00:21:14.050
But I do have another user account
that's logged in this machine.

419
00:21:14.050 --> 00:21:18.625
Now when I did the switch user,
it shows their state as disconnected but

420
00:21:18.625 --> 00:21:20.665
that's not the same as being logged off,
right?

421
00:21:20.665 --> 00:21:25.515
Disconnected means, their applications are
still running, in fact if we go back to

422
00:21:25.515 --> 00:21:29.985
processes I'll see that Mike, that user
account does have some processes running.

423
00:21:31.095 --> 00:21:35.345
So they are taking up resources and what
can happen with that user switching and

424
00:21:35.345 --> 00:21:36.910
switch user capabilities.

425
00:21:36.910 --> 00:21:40.110
You can have people switch it,
my parents were bad about this.

426
00:21:40.110 --> 00:21:41.389
I have had some co-workers
that were bad about this.

427
00:21:41.389 --> 00:21:46.210
Instead of logging off they would just
switch user accounts to another one.

428
00:21:46.210 --> 00:21:47.680
And before you know it there
can be four or five or

429
00:21:47.680 --> 00:21:50.720
six users that are logged
onto that system.

430
00:21:50.720 --> 00:21:54.350
Their status is disconnected but their
profile is loaded up, that's being stored

431
00:21:54.350 --> 00:21:58.150
memory, they've got applications
running that's taking up resources.

432
00:21:58.150 --> 00:22:01.210
So if I've got someone that I wanna
kick off I can do it from here.

433
00:22:01.210 --> 00:22:03.480
I can say why is my system running so
slow?

434
00:22:03.480 --> 00:22:07.640
Oh, look there are seven different user
accounts logged on to this system and

435
00:22:07.640 --> 00:22:09.490
four of them aren't even at work today.

436
00:22:09.490 --> 00:22:12.220
So I can come in here and
I can do a couple of things.

437
00:22:12.220 --> 00:22:15.110
If they were remote I
could disconnect them.

438
00:22:15.110 --> 00:22:20.120
If they are already disconnected I can log
them off I can also send them a message.

439
00:22:20.120 --> 00:22:25.326
And it's just gonna pop
a little net send on there and

440
00:22:25.326 --> 00:22:29.010
I'm gonna say, are you still here?

441
00:22:29.010 --> 00:22:29.654
And I'll go ahead and send that.

442
00:22:29.654 --> 00:22:33.973
And then what the other user would see
if I switch over to that other account.

443
00:22:38.170 --> 00:22:40.370
We'll log on as Mike.

444
00:22:45.390 --> 00:22:50.770
And here we go, I get a message from
lab administrator saying, are you here?

445
00:22:50.770 --> 00:22:54.810
If I was, I could maybe call him up or
say something.

446
00:22:54.810 --> 00:22:59.650
If I wasn't though, if I didn't respond,
I might put something in that message.

447
00:22:59.650 --> 00:23:03.270
Hey look, if you're still using
this computer, give me a call, or

448
00:23:03.270 --> 00:23:05.610
stop by my office, or something like that.

449
00:23:05.610 --> 00:23:10.000
But if they don't respond,
I can assume, well, incorrectly or

450
00:23:10.000 --> 00:23:11.810
not, what assuming spells.

451
00:23:11.810 --> 00:23:13.760
But I can say, all right, Mike's not here.

452
00:23:13.760 --> 00:23:15.310
He's not responding to my message.

453
00:23:15.310 --> 00:23:18.650
I'm tired of him sucking up the resources
and slowing this machine down.

454
00:23:18.650 --> 00:23:20.680
I'm gonna go ahead and log him off.

455
00:23:20.680 --> 00:23:21.700
So I click log off.

456
00:23:21.700 --> 00:23:22.610
It says, are you sure?

457
00:23:22.610 --> 00:23:24.230
Because they might lose data.

458
00:23:24.230 --> 00:23:25.670
So something that you've
got to keep in mind,

459
00:23:25.670 --> 00:23:29.230
you don't want to just kick them off any
old time you see them on your machine.

460
00:23:29.230 --> 00:23:31.020
If they've got a Word
document half typed and

461
00:23:31.020 --> 00:23:33.790
not saved,
they could potentially lose that.

462
00:23:33.790 --> 00:23:35.990
Now you just log off user, and

463
00:23:35.990 --> 00:23:39.570
bada bing, they're gone, and
now some of those resources are freed up.

464
00:23:39.570 --> 00:23:43.267
If I go back over to Processes,
notice if I sort this by User Name,

465
00:23:43.267 --> 00:23:45.642
there's no Mike listed in here anymore.

466
00:23:45.642 --> 00:23:49.694
So I freed up those resources so
that my system can perform better.

467
00:23:49.694 --> 00:23:53.422
And it wasn't necessary,
Mike wasn't even here today, so

468
00:23:53.422 --> 00:23:55.699
Easy way to free up those resources.

469
00:23:55.699 --> 00:23:58.460
>> It really is.
It's a great little utility for us.

470
00:23:58.460 --> 00:23:59.980
And we normally take this, and

471
00:23:59.980 --> 00:24:03.830
we tie it together with something
that we call that Resource Monitor.

472
00:24:03.830 --> 00:24:07.967
Especially if we're trying to hone in on
what specifically may be causing us some

473
00:24:07.967 --> 00:24:08.560
issues.

474
00:24:08.560 --> 00:24:09.572
>> Exactly.

475
00:24:09.572 --> 00:24:12.120
All right, so I told you guys
that we would go back over to

476
00:24:12.120 --> 00:24:15.380
this Resource Monitor, so
let's not make a liar out of me.

477
00:24:15.380 --> 00:24:19.350
Back over to the Performance Tab,
I'm going to click on Resource Monitor.

478
00:24:19.350 --> 00:24:24.120
Now we've had Task Manager in Windows
since as far back as I can remember.

479
00:24:24.120 --> 00:24:26.010
Resource Monitor is relatively new.

480
00:24:26.010 --> 00:24:28.420
Vista, I believe,
is when this one came out.

481
00:24:28.420 --> 00:24:31.900
And Ronnie, I know I like to call
it Task Manager on steroids,

482
00:24:31.900 --> 00:24:34.400
is really what it comes down to, right?

483
00:24:34.400 --> 00:24:35.010
>> It really is.

484
00:24:35.010 --> 00:24:38.160
You get so much more detail,
especially if you think that there's

485
00:24:38.160 --> 00:24:41.480
one particular program causing it,
whereas the other one is really a summary.

486
00:24:41.480 --> 00:24:45.120
You still get the summary information that
you see over on the right-hand side, but

487
00:24:45.120 --> 00:24:46.330
that's pretty much about it.

488
00:24:46.330 --> 00:24:49.580
But notice that over here on the left
-hand side, you actually not

489
00:24:49.580 --> 00:24:53.780
only get an overview, which is a summary,
with more detail behind it.

490
00:24:53.780 --> 00:24:58.530
But notice that each one of those
tabs we well, CPU, Memory, Disc,

491
00:24:58.530 --> 00:25:02.810
and Network, again all those performance
things that we're actually talking about.

492
00:25:02.810 --> 00:25:04.750
And each one actually
allows you to expand and

493
00:25:04.750 --> 00:25:07.050
allows you to see some
of the different things.

494
00:25:07.050 --> 00:25:10.530
And this is where if you actually are one
of those persons with a keen eye,

495
00:25:10.530 --> 00:25:13.260
and you're looking for
a specific instance, or

496
00:25:13.260 --> 00:25:16.990
you actually are suspecting
a specific problem happening or

497
00:25:16.990 --> 00:25:19.790
a program causing it, you can actually
try and filter it out right here.

498
00:25:19.790 --> 00:25:20.400
>> Absolutely.

499
00:25:20.400 --> 00:25:23.380
So you can see, as Ronnie said,
just detailed information.

500
00:25:23.380 --> 00:25:25.690
This first screen is
a lot like Task Manager.

501
00:25:25.690 --> 00:25:28.850
I can see what's going on in CPU,
what's going on the disk,

502
00:25:28.850 --> 00:25:32.602
the network if there was anything,
as well as RAM or memory.

503
00:25:32.602 --> 00:25:37.268
Look at these nice little mini graphs
here that show me some information.

504
00:25:37.268 --> 00:25:41.080
And then on the left or the right pane
over here, I've got a similar view to what

505
00:25:41.080 --> 00:25:46.530
we saw in Task Manager, CPU and memory,
but I also get disk and network.

506
00:25:46.530 --> 00:25:48.850
And this is just the Overview tab, right?

507
00:25:48.850 --> 00:25:52.590
I mean, this is a lot of information,
and I have not left the Overview tab.

508
00:25:52.590 --> 00:25:55.240
If I want to see a little more
detailed information on the CPU,

509
00:25:55.240 --> 00:25:56.830
I go to the CPU tab.

510
00:25:56.830 --> 00:26:02.290
And now I've got processes, I've got
services, I've got associated handles,

511
00:26:02.290 --> 00:26:05.080
I've got associated modules.

512
00:26:05.080 --> 00:26:09.384
So if I come up here and
select VirtualBox, for example.

513
00:26:09.384 --> 00:26:14.580
All right, now I can see what
services the VirtualBox is running,

514
00:26:14.580 --> 00:26:18.040
what handles it's running, and
what associated modules it's running.

515
00:26:18.040 --> 00:26:21.250
What's really cool, that's what these
little check marks are for over here,

516
00:26:21.250 --> 00:26:26.570
is we can filter it down to see
a particular process or service.

517
00:26:26.570 --> 00:26:27.910
I see the totals.

518
00:26:27.910 --> 00:26:29.940
I wanna know what VirtualBox is using.

519
00:26:29.940 --> 00:26:31.460
Well, now I can see that.

520
00:26:31.460 --> 00:26:35.700
And when I go to these other tabs, it's
already filtered by that same VirtualBox.

521
00:26:35.700 --> 00:26:40.520
I've got memory over here,
I've got disk, as well as disk activity.

522
00:26:40.520 --> 00:26:43.560
Notice it's filtered by VBox service.

523
00:26:43.560 --> 00:26:48.400
I got Network, and I come over here,
and I can see filtered by VBox service.

524
00:26:48.400 --> 00:26:48.930
All right?

525
00:26:48.930 --> 00:26:52.542
Another cool thing that I always like
to show is when you filter this,

526
00:26:52.542 --> 00:26:54.847
not only does it filter
all the other tabs for

527
00:26:54.847 --> 00:26:59.169
that particular item that you've selected,
watch this little graph over here.

528
00:26:59.169 --> 00:27:03.278
If I go and take, I don't know,
PerfMon usually is a good one.

529
00:27:03.278 --> 00:27:05.036
You'll see that it does that filtering,
but

530
00:27:05.036 --> 00:27:07.095
look at the orange line
it put on my graph.

531
00:27:07.095 --> 00:27:10.790
The green graph represents
my total CPU usage.

532
00:27:10.790 --> 00:27:14.730
That orange shows me the percentage
of that usage that's being used by

533
00:27:14.730 --> 00:27:15.950
Performance Monitor.

534
00:27:15.950 --> 00:27:19.720
Because I know I've launched Resource
Monitor here, Performance Monitor is

535
00:27:19.720 --> 00:27:24.230
what's in the background feeding a lot of
this information over to Resource Monitor.

536
00:27:24.230 --> 00:27:26.990
So I knew it would be
sucking up some resources.

537
00:27:26.990 --> 00:27:28.120
So that's really cool.

538
00:27:28.120 --> 00:27:29.990
I've done copy processes,

539
00:27:29.990 --> 00:27:34.300
where I've gone from hard drive to hard
drive, hard drive to USB hard drive.

540
00:27:34.300 --> 00:27:35.793
And I can compare the two in here.

541
00:27:35.793 --> 00:27:38.359
And look at the read and
write speeds and things like that.

542
00:27:38.359 --> 00:27:41.220
You can do some really neat stuff in here.

543
00:27:41.220 --> 00:27:44.815
It is all still read only,
like Task Manager.

544
00:27:44.815 --> 00:27:46.049
I can end a task.

545
00:27:46.049 --> 00:27:49.114
And that's about all I can do.

546
00:27:49.114 --> 00:27:54.635
End a task, end a process,
end a process tree, suspend a process.

547
00:27:54.635 --> 00:27:56.420
Not a lot more.

548
00:27:56.420 --> 00:28:00.175
It's real-time data, meaning that I
can't save any of this information.

549
00:28:00.175 --> 00:28:02.260
If it'll let me uncheck that.

550
00:28:02.260 --> 00:28:03.660
I can't save any of this information.

551
00:28:03.660 --> 00:28:07.330
So as soon as this graph information
scrolls off to the left,

552
00:28:07.330 --> 00:28:08.230
it's gonna be gone.

553
00:28:08.230 --> 00:28:10.250
I can't go back and retrieve it, right?

554
00:28:10.250 --> 00:28:12.250
>> Yeah,
there is just a lot of detail in here.

555
00:28:12.250 --> 00:28:16.070
But usually more than I'm ever
actually going to try and pinpoint.

556
00:28:16.070 --> 00:28:20.640
But if I actually did realize that there
is only one program that I'm suspecting,

557
00:28:20.640 --> 00:28:23.810
that I think is causing this,
I can go in and actually find out,

558
00:28:23.810 --> 00:28:27.340
is that the one that's really hogging
up all the resources on my computer or

559
00:28:27.340 --> 00:28:29.520
not, and even find the details about it.

560
00:28:29.520 --> 00:28:31.060
And you can't beat that.

561
00:28:31.060 --> 00:28:33.060
It's not an extra program you have to buy.

562
00:28:33.060 --> 00:28:34.640
Now, are there actually
other programs out there?

563
00:28:34.640 --> 00:28:35.380
You better believe it.

564
00:28:35.380 --> 00:28:38.990
There's a ton of other programs out there,
that will actually do all this.

565
00:28:38.990 --> 00:28:40.986
This is built in to that user's machine,
and

566
00:28:40.986 --> 00:28:43.464
it's something you can take
advantage of very easily.

567
00:28:43.464 --> 00:28:44.922
>> All right well, Ronnie, I tell you.

568
00:28:44.922 --> 00:28:50.080
That's a lot of information about
Task Manager and that Resource Monitor.

569
00:28:50.080 --> 00:28:51.520
Did we miss anything, leave anything out?

570
00:28:51.520 --> 00:28:53.750
>> Not really so far, right?

571
00:28:53.750 --> 00:28:56.590
Remember that this is something
that you are gonna be called on to

572
00:28:56.590 --> 00:29:00.570
do as a technician at times, is to be
able to actually understand some of these

573
00:29:00.570 --> 00:29:02.920
monitoring tools that we've
been taking a look at.

574
00:29:02.920 --> 00:29:05.810
The Task Manager,
realize the control that you have there.

575
00:29:05.810 --> 00:29:09.800
Take a look at the Performance, Resource
Monitor, so that way you can actually

576
00:29:09.800 --> 00:29:12.280
tell where you're actually
getting hit on your resources.

577
00:29:12.280 --> 00:29:14.820
And actually be able to improve
the performance of your machine.

578
00:29:14.820 --> 00:29:17.400
Great tools built into Windows 7.

579
00:29:17.400 --> 00:29:20.120
>> Alright,
we want to thank everybody for tuning in.

580
00:29:20.120 --> 00:29:22.660
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

581
00:29:22.660 --> 00:29:23.995
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.
>> And we'll see you next time.

582

>> So it gives me some flexibility there.

688
00:34:39.560 --> 00:34:40.160
Right?

689
00:34:40.160 --> 00:34:40.750
>> Sure does.

690
00:34:40.750 --> 00:34:43.950
You know, there's some of these features
I haven't really gone that in depth to

691
00:34:43.950 --> 00:34:48.200
actually be able to think about creating
alert tasks that will alert something.

692
00:34:48.200 --> 00:34:50.280
That it could do what
we're talking about here,

693
00:34:50.280 --> 00:34:53.920
so it might be where it sends them
like an email or something like that.

694
00:34:53.920 --> 00:34:56.680
>> Exactly, I can even have every one
second if it's up above one percent,

695
00:34:56.680 --> 00:35:00.870
my inbox is now flooded and Don's calling
me saying why is your mailbox so big?

696
00:35:00.870 --> 00:35:04.280
So we go ahead and click okay on that,
and then you do have to start it.

697
00:35:04.280 --> 00:35:08.420
So I'll go ahead and click on it and
choose start and now it's running, but

698
00:35:08.420 --> 00:35:09.210
I don't see anything.

699
00:35:09.210 --> 00:35:12.300
I'm not going to see a graph,
I'm not going to see any information but

700
00:35:12.300 --> 00:35:14.280
what's going to happen is it's going to,
well,

701
00:35:14.280 --> 00:35:17.250
whatever I chose to do when I
pulled up those properties.

702
00:35:17.250 --> 00:35:21.820
So let me open up a couple of things, make
my system try to get it over one percent,

703
00:35:21.820 --> 00:35:25.070
which shouldn't be too much of
a challenge on this virtual machine.

704
00:35:25.070 --> 00:35:27.660
And then I'm going to go ahead and
stop that guy.

705
00:35:29.760 --> 00:35:30.830
And let's see what happened.

706
00:35:30.830 --> 00:35:32.396
I'm gonna go over to my event viewer.

707
00:35:36.552 --> 00:35:40.350
And sometimes this is a little bit weird,
I'm gonna, let's see what happens here.

708
00:35:40.350 --> 00:35:41.030
I'm gonna go to Windows logs now,

709
00:35:41.030 --> 00:35:45.410
you saw where it said I'm gonna log
an entry into the application log.

710
00:35:45.410 --> 00:35:47.340
So, I'm looking at my application log now.

711
00:35:49.545 --> 00:35:53.340
I'll see that there are no events that
had to do with my performance monitor.

712
00:35:54.490 --> 00:35:55.720
All right.

713
00:35:55.720 --> 00:35:56.660
Nothing there.

714
00:35:56.660 --> 00:35:58.670
And this is just something
you have to know.

715
00:35:58.670 --> 00:36:03.496
I don't know why it says that, I think
they've changed the log filer used and

716
00:36:03.496 --> 00:36:06.702
they never updated
the interface to reflect that.

717
00:36:06.702 --> 00:36:10.158
They need to modify that because where
it's actually gonna go is down here in

718
00:36:10.158 --> 00:36:11.299
application services.

719
00:36:11.299 --> 00:36:15.022
>> [LAUGH]
>> Microsoft Windows and

720
00:36:15.022 --> 00:36:18.938
then diagnosis PLA operational.

721
00:36:18.938 --> 00:36:20.192
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know, right?

722
00:36:20.192 --> 00:36:21.900
Ronnie buried way in there.

723
00:36:21.900 --> 00:36:22.654
>> That's intuitive.

724
00:36:22.654 --> 00:36:24.813
>> [LAUGH]
>> You knew right where to go didn't you?

725
00:36:24.813 --> 00:36:27.104
>> [LAUGH]
>> I would have known exactly never

726
00:36:27.104 --> 00:36:27.730
where to go.

727
00:36:27.730 --> 00:36:32.080
And there I can see, data collection set,
data processor alerts stopped.

728
00:36:32.080 --> 00:36:36.650
Right, that's where I turned it off,
right before that I can see

729
00:36:36.650 --> 00:36:40.240
performance counter percent process
time has tripped the alert threshold.

730
00:36:40.240 --> 00:36:42.960
The counter value of 11
is over the limit of 1.

731
00:36:42.960 --> 00:36:46.080
And if I scroll down through
these messages here,

732
00:36:46.080 --> 00:36:49.130
I should see I get one every one second.

733
00:36:49.130 --> 00:36:53.560
If you watch the log time there, every
one second it was measuring that counter,

734
00:36:53.560 --> 00:36:56.080
and it's recording those events,
all right.

735
00:36:56.080 --> 00:37:00.220
So that's a way that I can still stay
on top of performance, but not have to

736
00:37:00.220 --> 00:37:03.440
sit there and monitor it all day long or
have it open on a window beside me and

737
00:37:03.440 --> 00:37:05.850
keep glancing over it and
things like that.

738
00:37:05.850 --> 00:37:08.610
>> It really does seem
like a very handy tool,

739
00:37:08.610 --> 00:37:10.600
especially when you're incredibly busy.

740
00:37:10.600 --> 00:37:13.030
But you know on the one system,
if you know you're looking for

741
00:37:13.030 --> 00:37:16.530
that one event and you're actually
trying to see if it is gonna trigger,

742
00:37:16.530 --> 00:37:17.515
it's probably the best way to go.

743
00:37:17.515 --> 00:37:20.630
>> Absolutely.You know,
I don't find that as useful as

744
00:37:20.630 --> 00:37:23.920
clients unless I know there's a problem
and I might set up an alert or

745
00:37:23.920 --> 00:37:27.940
something to get notified if that
processor spikes or something tell you

746
00:37:27.940 --> 00:37:31.600
where I really find that one handy is
on file servers and things like that.

747
00:37:31.600 --> 00:37:34.640
Cuz you could do available
megabytes right?

748
00:37:34.640 --> 00:37:38.840
And so I can have it monitoring
my hard drive space for me,

749
00:37:38.840 --> 00:37:46.100
if available megabytes drops below 1,024,
trigger an alert in the event log.

750
00:37:46.100 --> 00:37:49.990
And then in the event log it
can say send me an email.

751
00:37:49.990 --> 00:37:53.187
So those files rivers, if any of them
ever drops below a gig of free space,

752
00:37:53.187 --> 00:37:54.700
I'm gonna get an email.

753
00:37:54.700 --> 00:37:58.130
I don't have to log into the servers
anytime or go look at it manually, or

754
00:37:58.130 --> 00:37:58.790
anything like that.

755
00:37:58.790 --> 00:38:01.100
So you get a little creative
with this stuff and

756
00:38:01.100 --> 00:38:02.970
you can make it pretty darn powerful.

757
00:38:02.970 --> 00:38:07.940
>> Yeah it seems like a handy tool to
really keep you up to date on what's going

758
00:38:07.940 --> 00:38:10.450
on, instead of you having to go
to search for the information.

759
00:38:10.450 --> 00:38:11.490
>> Absolutely.

760
00:38:11.490 --> 00:38:14.320
All right Ronnie, well that's about
I've got on performance monitor,

761
00:38:14.320 --> 00:38:16.010
anything else we can throw in there?

762
00:38:16.010 --> 00:38:19.960
>> Nothing that I can throw in there, but
it's actually a incredible tool, right.

763
00:38:19.960 --> 00:38:22.440
So, don't overlook it.

764
00:38:22.440 --> 00:38:25.840
It's easier to say, you know,
we've got third party tool to do all this.

765
00:38:25.840 --> 00:38:28.840
And if you're comfortable with that,
that's perfectly fine.

766
00:38:28.840 --> 00:38:32.450
But running the Windows world, they went
in and built this tool in for you, and so

767
00:38:32.450 --> 00:38:34.950
there may be times when you
are actually supporting,

768
00:38:34.950 --> 00:38:39.000
maybe there's not your main job, maybe
a night job and maybe another job and you

769
00:38:39.000 --> 00:38:42.450
actually have to do something like this,
it's right there, take advantage of it.

770
00:38:42.450 --> 00:38:43.720
>> And
you guys can play with this at home right?

771
00:38:43.720 --> 00:38:44.650
>> RIght.
>> It's hosted on a server,

772
00:38:44.650 --> 00:38:46.120
there wasn't anything I had to download,

773
00:38:46.120 --> 00:38:49.500
it is built in to your Windows operating
system so take advantage of that.

774
00:38:49.500 --> 00:38:51.786
Jump in there, play around with it,
get comfortable with it.

775
00:38:51.786 --> 00:38:53.177
Because you're going to end up needing
them when you end up in the real world.

776
00:38:53.177 --> 00:38:54.892
>> Right.

1

2

Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.765 --> 00:00:14.855
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:14.855 --> 00:00:16.475
With me today is Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:16.475 --> 00:00:17.275
How are you, Ronnie?

6
00:00:17.275 --> 00:00:18.185
>> I'm doing fine today.

7
00:00:18.185 --> 00:00:21.190
It's another wonderful day
to be here in the studio and

8
00:00:21.190 --> 00:00:23.293
to be taking a look at some Windows 7.

9
00:00:23.293 --> 00:00:27.403
And today, specifically, talking
about the reliability of Windows 7.

10
00:00:27.403 --> 00:00:28.820
>> Reliability of Windows 7.

11
00:00:28.820 --> 00:00:31.142
It's so reliable, right?

12
00:00:31.142 --> 00:00:31.988
>> Right.
>> It is.

13
00:00:31.988 --> 00:00:36.700
It was a pretty, all kidding aside,
it was a pretty stable operating system.

14
00:00:36.700 --> 00:00:38.020
>> It was an incredibly, and

15
00:00:38.020 --> 00:00:42.560
at least for my perspective,
incredibly stable operating system.

16
00:00:42.560 --> 00:00:47.470
Because there was relatively little things
that you could actually do to the system

17
00:00:47.470 --> 00:00:48.330
to really bring it down,

18
00:00:48.330 --> 00:00:50.670
unless you actually start adding
some weird, weird programs.

19
00:00:50.670 --> 00:00:53.560
And you probably didn't have
any real problems with it.

20
00:00:53.560 --> 00:00:55.400
But the nice thing about Windows 7 though.

21
00:00:55.400 --> 00:00:59.800
It actually includes a tool, that we are
gonna specifically take a look at, to help

22
00:00:59.800 --> 00:01:03.440
monitor not only some of the different
performance things that we've taken a look

23
00:01:03.440 --> 00:01:07.670
at, such as Performance Monitor, but
actually reliability unto itself.

24
00:01:07.670 --> 00:01:10.192
So, Mike, before we get started
at taking a look at that,

25
00:01:10.192 --> 00:01:13.340
let's go ahead and define that
performance versus reliability again.

26
00:01:13.340 --> 00:01:14.037
>> Absolutely.

27
00:01:14.037 --> 00:01:17.162
We're talking about reliability,
and you'll hear people talk

28
00:01:17.162 --> 00:01:20.980
about reliability and performance and
try to use those guys interchangeably.

29
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:23.070
And they really do mean
two separate things.

30
00:01:23.070 --> 00:01:26.330
Performance is about
your perception of speed.

31
00:01:26.330 --> 00:01:28.950
When I open up Excel,
how long does it take to open?

32
00:01:28.950 --> 00:01:32.490
When I go to log on, how long does
it take me to get to my desktop?

33
00:01:32.490 --> 00:01:33.900
And performance is very relative.

34
00:01:33.900 --> 00:01:37.490
It really depends on who's
perception we're talking about.

35
00:01:37.490 --> 00:01:41.170
Ronnie and I could take a laptop and
pass it back and forth between us.

36
00:01:41.170 --> 00:01:42.635
I might think the laptop is very fast,

37
00:01:42.635 --> 00:01:46.400
cuz compared to my piece of junk,
it is a lot faster.

38
00:01:46.400 --> 00:01:48.300
But Ronnie takes the same laptop and says,

39
00:01:48.300 --> 00:01:52.550
this thing is slow as heck, because
compared to his laptop, it's a lot slower.

40
00:01:52.550 --> 00:01:56.240
So same laptop, one person says it's slow,
the other person says it's fast.

41
00:01:58.490 --> 00:02:02.770
Performance is very perception-based.

42
00:02:02.770 --> 00:02:04.390
Yes, it's very subjective.

43
00:02:04.390 --> 00:02:09.150
Reliability, on the other hand, is how
something conforms to expected behavior.

44
00:02:09.150 --> 00:02:11.310
It has nothing to do with performance.

45
00:02:11.310 --> 00:02:15.740
If my application crashes, that's not what
I expect, that's a reliability issue.

46
00:02:15.740 --> 00:02:18.900
If my operating system blue screens,
that's a reliability issue.

47
00:02:18.900 --> 00:02:20.790
That's not what I expect it to do.

48
00:02:20.790 --> 00:02:24.390
But I can have something that works fast,
it's a very fast laptop, but

49
00:02:24.390 --> 00:02:25.550
it crashes all the time.

50
00:02:25.550 --> 00:02:28.240
Great performance, very bad reliability.

51
00:02:28.240 --> 00:02:32.130
I could have something that never crashed,
but it's slow as heck.

52
00:02:32.130 --> 00:02:35.010
So great reliability, poor performance.

53
00:02:35.010 --> 00:02:37.540
They're not related in any way, right?

54
00:02:37.540 --> 00:02:38.400
>> That's true.

55
00:02:38.400 --> 00:02:40.410
Whenever you start taking
a look at reliability,

56
00:02:40.410 --> 00:02:44.640
one of the chief things that we want
to actually understand as a technician

57
00:02:44.640 --> 00:02:49.140
is what causes the computer
to become unreliable.

58
00:02:49.140 --> 00:02:52.910
What is it on our systems, or is it a part
of our systems, is it an application,

59
00:02:52.910 --> 00:02:56.630
is it the hardware, is it the operating
system itself, is it updates?

60
00:02:56.630 --> 00:02:57.980
Whatever it might be.

61
00:02:57.980 --> 00:03:01.810
What is it that causes that
system to actually be unreliable?

62
00:03:01.810 --> 00:03:03.556
And the problem that we have is simple.

63
00:03:03.556 --> 00:03:07.460
Some weeks, like the past couple
of weeks to me, have gone so

64
00:03:07.460 --> 00:03:11.613
fast I didn't even realize that
two weeks have just about past.

65
00:03:11.613 --> 00:03:13.860
And there are some weeks where
it's actually really slow.

66
00:03:13.860 --> 00:03:15.280
So all the sudden when I'm talking about,

67
00:03:15.280 --> 00:03:19.330
my computer's been actually fairly
reliable for the past week.

68
00:03:19.330 --> 00:03:22.470
I may not actually mean anything but
the past couple of days, and

69
00:03:22.470 --> 00:03:24.689
I'm not able to actually
take a look at that.

70
00:03:24.689 --> 00:03:28.730
But with Windows 7 though,
they have a tool inside that we call

71
00:03:28.730 --> 00:03:33.860
the Reliability Monitor, and this
particular tool gives us historical data.

72
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:37.674
And it can actually go ahead and
is actually rated on a scale of 1 to 10,

73
00:03:37.674 --> 00:03:40.502
10 being the most reliable,
1 being unreliable.

74
00:03:40.502 --> 00:03:43.329
And then we can actually graph
that in the past history so

75
00:03:43.329 --> 00:03:47.241
that we can actually see where our
computer's actually been more reliable,

76
00:03:47.241 --> 00:03:49.889
and where it's actually
become less reliable, and

77
00:03:49.889 --> 00:03:53.406
even see some of the causes that
would have actually shown that to us.

78
00:03:53.406 --> 00:03:53.996
>> Absolutely.
Cuz,

79
00:03:53.996 --> 00:03:58.220
you know, having a fast machine is great,
but if the thing crashes all the time, or

80
00:03:58.220 --> 00:04:02.510
if an application hangs up all the time,
that is frustrating to an end user.

81
00:04:02.510 --> 00:04:06.110
And it means a loss in productivity,
because they've gotta reboot the system,

82
00:04:06.110 --> 00:04:08.690
or they've gotta wait for
the application to free up.

83
00:04:08.690 --> 00:04:12.210
And it's a bad experience, and
it's not good for business,

84
00:04:12.210 --> 00:04:15.020
because I've got employees
that are not being productive.

85
00:04:15.020 --> 00:04:18.520
So, it's nice that Microsoft gives us the
ability to use this Reliability Monitor.

86
00:04:18.520 --> 00:04:22.520
As Ronnie said, all it's doing
it's recording certain events.

87
00:04:22.520 --> 00:04:27.390
It takes a look at hardware and
software issues, as well as some software

88
00:04:27.390 --> 00:04:32.120
installations, and
it tracks that on a little counter.

89
00:04:32.120 --> 00:04:35.520
In fact, I've got it pulled up here on my
system, if we want to take a look at that.

90
00:04:35.520 --> 00:04:38.300
This is the Reliability Monitor, and

91
00:04:38.300 --> 00:04:42.340
what it's gonna do is it's going to,
any time something happens.

92
00:04:42.340 --> 00:04:43.030
Let's back up.

93
00:04:43.030 --> 00:04:44.330
Ronnie said it's on a scale of 1 to 10.

94
00:04:44.330 --> 00:04:49.160
We're gonna start out on a 10, 10 is
the most stable, 1 is the least stable.

95
00:04:49.160 --> 00:04:52.520
Any time an event occurs,
it's gonna record it in here, and

96
00:04:52.520 --> 00:04:56.010
I'm gonna take a hit on
my reliability scale.

97
00:04:56.010 --> 00:04:58.490
So I can look at this little
line going across the top,

98
00:04:58.490 --> 00:05:03.070
and I can see what my reliability is,
it's a ten, and

99
00:05:03.070 --> 00:05:07.120
I can see on this particular day,
for example, I had some issues.

100
00:05:07.120 --> 00:05:08.770
What's really cool about it is,

101
00:05:08.770 --> 00:05:13.600
it goes back until the day from when you
installed Windows in the first place.

102
00:05:13.600 --> 00:05:16.970
Now this is a virtual machine, and it's
only been running since the 22nd of June,

103
00:05:16.970 --> 00:05:20.050
so there's not a lot of information here.

104
00:05:20.050 --> 00:05:23.030
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna
show you the Reliability Monitor

105
00:05:23.030 --> 00:05:25.860
off of my laptop that
I'm actually sitting at.

106
00:05:25.860 --> 00:05:30.660
It is running Windows 8, but you'll see
the Reliability Monitor hasn't changed, so

107
00:05:30.660 --> 00:05:33.820
this is the exact same thing
you would see in Windows 7.

108
00:05:33.820 --> 00:05:37.610
So we kind of forget about
the whole Windows 8 thing.

109
00:05:37.610 --> 00:05:39.035
And here's my reliability.

110
00:05:39.035 --> 00:05:41.155
And you can see that on
this particular day,

111
00:05:41.155 --> 00:05:43.635
for example, I took a hit in reliability.

112
00:05:43.635 --> 00:05:45.185
Something happened.

113
00:05:45.185 --> 00:05:48.235
What's cool is that I can click on
that day, and I can see what happened.

114
00:05:48.235 --> 00:05:50.775
Oh, VirtualBox stopped working.

115
00:05:50.775 --> 00:05:52.955
And that's why I've got this red X here.

116
00:05:52.955 --> 00:05:55.725
And that's why I took
a hit in my reliability.

117
00:05:55.725 --> 00:05:57.735
And then nothing happened,
nothing happened,

118
00:05:57.735 --> 00:06:00.080
my reliability is working its way back up.

119
00:06:00.080 --> 00:06:03.240
And then another hit, so
I can come see what happened on that day.

120
00:06:03.240 --> 00:06:05.390
Oh, Internet Explorer stopped working.

121
00:06:05.390 --> 00:06:07.750
All right, so
the two events weren't related, so

122
00:06:07.750 --> 00:06:10.090
I'm probably not going
to think too much of it.

123
00:06:10.090 --> 00:06:10.870
I keep going.

124
00:06:10.870 --> 00:06:12.340
I don't see any more major events.

125
00:06:12.340 --> 00:06:13.490
Nothing happened.

126
00:06:13.490 --> 00:06:18.100
The idea is if I come in here and I see
these hits day after day after day, or

127
00:06:18.100 --> 00:06:20.940
once every Monday,
I can click on each one of those days and

128
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:22.810
try to find the common denominator.

129
00:06:22.810 --> 00:06:27.000
What is it that's causing
this reliability hit?

130
00:06:27.000 --> 00:06:30.270
And as we've said, we can go back
to the day I installed Windows.

131
00:06:30.270 --> 00:06:33.170
It can be viewed by days, as it is here.

132
00:06:33.170 --> 00:06:35.520
I can also view it by weeks.

133
00:06:35.520 --> 00:06:38.530
So now both of those hits
that I saw on separate days

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take an in depth look at access control. They look at NTFS permissions, both standard and special. Then they demonstrate how NTFS permissions are inherited, and how to change the way permissions are inherited.

So that way we eliminate that step, and

00:30:48.921 --> 00:30:53.617

00:30:53.617 --> 00:30:57.140
permissions that restricted me or
the NTFS permissions.

00:30:57.140 --> 00:31:01.333
So in a real world situation
you're gonna see that more often.

00:31:01.333 --> 00:31:04.439
I'm not gonna say you're gonna
see it a 100% of the time but

00:31:04.439 --> 00:31:07.854

00:31:07.854 --> 00:31:09.680

00:31:09.680 --> 00:31:14.700

00:31:24.507 --> 00:31:26.690

00:31:26.690 --> 00:31:29.230

>> They're always gonna be checked, so

I don't really have to worry about

00:31:32.815 --> 00:31:37.405

environments, they might say-

00:32:00.590 --> 00:32:01.246
>> [LAUGH]

00:32:01.246 --> 00:32:01.997
>> That's horrible, action.

>> Don't listen to that guy on ITProTV.

00:32:03.639 --> 00:32:04.139

00:32:04.139 --> 00:32:05.399

You'd better only assign the share

permissions that they need and fine,

do that.

no Mike said, this is the way to do it.

No-

I'm just saying that we're seeing kind

00:32:22.540 --> 00:32:23.919
I would not be offended though-

the administrator and

647
00:32:41.763 --> 00:32:47.287
>> That is the nature of us trying to

00:33:08.470 --> 00:33:11.920

00:33:20.219 --> 00:33:20.921
>> Absolutely.

659
00:33:20.921 --> 00:33:23.610

00:33:23.610 --> 00:33:27.012
But I think we’ve covered NTFS and

you're going to deal with it

00:33:36.738 --> 00:33:38.848

00:33:38.848 --> 00:33:41.003

00:33:46.390 --> 00:33:47.482

the world, but

So I'm just going to call it

Oh, oh it doesn't like.

Just in case, somebody else gets

make sure you do put a password here,

00:29:09.430 --> 00:29:12.200
Now, this is not the only
place you can save it inside

of an active directory domain.

You may actually choose to save

by backing up there but for

00:29:20.420 --> 00:29:24.530
We're actually gonna use this of course

can actually encrypt other files later,
but let's go ahead and do it cuz I don't

561
00:29:31.570 --> 00:29:34.990
So, once we have this key and
it's saved and everything is fine.

562
00:29:34.990 --> 00:29:38.000
That is when we could actually
end up with some type of,

563
00:29:38.000 --> 00:29:41.000
well, corruption is what

564
00:29:41.000 --> 00:29:42.130
So, everything is saved.

565
00:29:42.130 --> 00:29:42.740
That's what we want.

566

So now, what if I go ahead and

567
00:29:48.970 --> 00:29:52.110
I'm gonna create a Microsoft
management console, and

00:29:52.110 --> 00:29:53.880
I'm gonna bring in
the certificate snap in.

569
00:29:55.690 --> 00:29:57.645
So, this is not something
you would do on purpose.

570
00:29:57.645 --> 00:30:00.420
>> [LAUGH]
>> But, yeah, hopefully not.

571
00:30:00.420 --> 00:30:02.500
This is not something
you would do on purpose.

572
00:30:02.500 --> 00:30:05.310
But what I'm trying to do is, I'm trying
to indicate that there is a corruption.

573
00:30:05.310 --> 00:30:07.400
Our sys certificate has gone missing.

574
00:30:07.400 --> 00:30:10.030
So if I could figure out a way to corrupt
the certificate, I probably could.

575
00:30:10.030 --> 00:30:11.611
But let's just delete it.

576
00:30:13.794 --> 00:30:15.809
All right, so
if I delete that certificate, and

577
00:30:15.809 --> 00:30:18.360
I'm not going to worry about saving it.

578
00:30:18.360 --> 00:30:18.860
No.

579
00:30:20.630 --> 00:30:24.610
Now, what normally would happen,
right, if a corruption happens is that

580
00:30:24.610 --> 00:30:27.390
we might actually not even notice
it until the following day.

581
00:30:27.390 --> 00:30:29.760
So, I'm going to log off as Mike and
the reason why I'm doing that is,

582
00:30:29.760 --> 00:30:34.540
now that we've already used it, it's
cached it inside of the ram at this point.

583
00:30:34.540 --> 00:30:35.850
But now, if I log off.

584
00:30:35.850 --> 00:30:38.750
Let's see if I can log back in here,
as Mike.

585
00:30:40.890 --> 00:30:41.485
>> One, two, three, four.
>> I'm trying.

586

[LAUGH]
>> I told you, I'm trying.

I can't type.

588
00:30:45.690 --> 00:30:50.620
So, as we log back in,
that file should be accessible to Mike.

589
00:30:50.620 --> 00:30:52.530
And Mike, is it gonna be accessible?

590
00:30:52.530 --> 00:30:53.840
>> That's a good question Ronnie.

591
00:30:53.840 --> 00:30:54.770
>> That is a good question.

592
00:30:54.770 --> 00:30:55.650
Let's see.

593
00:30:55.650 --> 00:30:58.450
So now, should get in, nope, there it is.

594
00:30:58.450 --> 00:30:59.180
Access denied.

595

Mike, you were denied
access to your own file.

596
00:31:01.020 --> 00:31:01.960
>> It's my own file.

597
00:31:01.960 --> 00:31:02.680
>> That is,

598
00:31:02.680 --> 00:31:05.805
that's pretty tough when you're actually
denied access to your own file.

599
00:31:05.805 --> 00:31:08.570
Cuz you don't know why you're
denied access to that file.

600
00:31:08.570 --> 00:31:11.690
You don't know if it actually got
corrupted or what else has happened.

601
00:31:11.690 --> 00:31:14.410
But that's usually a good indication
that something has happened

602
00:31:14.410 --> 00:31:17.290
to where now your certificate
is not accessible anymore.

603
00:31:17.290 --> 00:31:18.490
You can go and trace it out and

604
00:31:18.490 --> 00:31:21.410
see if it's actually still there
inside that personal folder.

605
00:31:21.410 --> 00:31:23.520
But, if it's not, what can you do?

606
00:31:23.520 --> 00:31:27.370
Well, the good thing is, since you have a
back up, you actually can import it right

607
00:31:27.370 --> 00:31:30.870
back in, and that's what we're hoping for
as long as you're not like me, and

608
00:31:30.870 --> 00:31:34.170
you would lose the actual
USB key at the same time.

609
00:31:34.170 --> 00:31:35.180
So, that's what we don't want.

610
00:31:35.180 --> 00:31:36.650
But here it is.

611
00:31:36.650 --> 00:31:37.720
And all I have to do now,

612
00:31:37.720 --> 00:31:40.580
there is my certificate,
all I have to do is select that.

613
00:31:40.580 --> 00:31:43.570
And there it is,
welcome to the import certificate wizard.

614
00:31:43.570 --> 00:31:44.790
And click next.

615
00:31:44.790 --> 00:31:49.380
And she shows the location and I need to
make sure I type in the correct password.

616
00:31:51.550 --> 00:31:52.380
And click next.

617
00:31:52.380 --> 00:31:54.190
I'm going to include all the properties.

618
00:31:54.190 --> 00:31:55.730
And I can choose where to place it,

619
00:31:55.730 --> 00:31:59.840
I'm going to let it automatically
place it wherever it wants to.

620
00:31:59.840 --> 00:32:04.120
Click finish and
now the import is successful.

621
00:32:04.120 --> 00:32:08.780
The only way to verify that is to
go back to that documents folder.

622
00:32:08.780 --> 00:32:11.230
And of course,
be able to open it up and there you go.

623
00:32:11.230 --> 00:32:12.790
You see it right there, Mike's File.

624
00:32:12.790 --> 00:32:13.960
That's encrypted.

625
00:32:13.960 --> 00:32:16.250
He can now gain access to it again.

626
00:32:16.250 --> 00:32:17.210
You do have to be careful.

627
00:32:17.210 --> 00:32:21.540
It's easy to think that these things
don't corrupt, but they can corrupt, and

628
00:32:21.540 --> 00:32:25.410
you can be in a world of trouble if
you don't have a backup to that.

629
00:32:25.410 --> 00:32:27.280
A lot of times in enterprises though,

630
00:32:27.280 --> 00:32:29.840
you don't even want to do
this to your own computer.

631
00:32:29.840 --> 00:32:33.870
You want them to actually manage it for
you cuz of instances like this.

632
00:32:33.870 --> 00:32:34.780
>> Yeah, absolutely.

633
00:32:34.780 --> 00:32:37.640
That private key ends up getting
stored in your user profile, and

634
00:32:37.640 --> 00:32:38.660
we know what can happen to that.

635
00:32:38.660 --> 00:32:41.290
As Ronnie said, it could become corrupt.

636
00:32:41.290 --> 00:32:42.593
We could delete the profile.

637
00:32:42.593 --> 00:32:44.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> The hard drive fails,

638
00:32:44.570 --> 00:32:46.630
you have to reinstall
the operating system.

639
00:32:46.630 --> 00:32:49.230
So don't think those keys are safe,
make sure you're backing them up.

640
00:32:49.230 --> 00:32:52.050
Otherwise, you will not
access those files again.

641
00:32:52.050 --> 00:32:56.140
>> Right, and that's something we've
got to really pay attention to.

642
00:32:56.140 --> 00:32:59.950
Best practices is to make sure
that those things are backed up.

643
00:32:59.950 --> 00:33:04.360
And also we think about it, right, to not
only be able to back those things up but

644
00:33:04.360 --> 00:33:08.790
also if we're working on a laptop,
use the BitLocker to make sure that

645
00:33:08.790 --> 00:33:13.430
our entire computers and our Windows 7
is actually getting updated for us too.

646
00:33:13.430 --> 00:33:16.350
Why?
Cuz these are things that really do

647
00:33:16.350 --> 00:33:18.120
make our job easier.

648
00:33:18.120 --> 00:33:21.240
Instead of wondering if something has
actually happened, if we know that we're

649
00:33:21.240 --> 00:33:24.990
actually securing it the way that we need
to we're actually closing the loophole for

650
00:33:24.990 --> 00:33:28.000
people to get in, or for
malicious software to get in for

651
00:33:28.000 --> 00:33:29.280
whatever we actually need.

652
00:33:29.280 --> 00:33:30.410
So this is at least,

653
00:33:30.410 --> 00:33:33.810
part of our job of making sure
that on every laptop we do this.

654
00:33:33.810 --> 00:33:37.240
Now, the way that we'd do that is what
we'd probably use group policy instead,

655
00:33:37.240 --> 00:33:40.290
to ensure that something like that happens
instead of just me manually going around

656
00:33:40.290 --> 00:33:43.870
to every single laptop and setting all
this stuff but that's what you want to do.

657
00:33:44.870 --> 00:33:46.770
All right, Ronnie, well,
thanks for that information.

658
00:33:46.770 --> 00:33:50.990
Another great episode here at ITProTV,
but that is gonna do it for this one.

659
00:33:50.990 --> 00:33:53.830
So signing off for ITProTV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

00:33:53.830 --> 00:33:54.490
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike look at troubleshooting network connectivity issues. They talk about determining the scope of the issue, and how that affects troubleshooting. They examine tools like ipconfig, ping, and netstat, and how to use them when troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Network Connectivity Issues
episodes.transcript:

1
00:00:00.321 --> 00:00:10.161
[MUSIC]

2

Hello and welcome to another

3

I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:15.360 --> 00:00:17.241
With me today is the famous Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:17.241 --> 00:00:18.411
[LAUGH] How you doing Ronnie?

6
00:00:18.411 --> 00:00:19.506
>> I am doing fine today.

7
00:00:19.506 --> 00:00:22.792
Today is another day that we get to
talk about supporting Windows 7.

8
00:00:22.792 --> 00:00:25.230
Remember that what we're trying to
do is not really prepare so much for

10
00:00:29.000 --> 00:00:32.440

11

inside of the enterprise and

00:00:35.840 --> 00:00:38.030
But, really more about that

Some of the tools that we need to as well.

16
00:00:46.790 --> 00:00:50.030
so, we do want to take some time and

And also just make sure that we understand

00:00:52.860 --> 00:00:56.680
that we actually tend to follow, to make
sure we're effective troubleshooters.

19
00:00:56.680 --> 00:00:57.519
>> Yeah, absolutely.
You know,

20
00:00:57.519 --> 00:00:58.751
networking is one of those things.

21
00:00:58.751 --> 00:01:01.610
I love my computer, it's great,

22
00:01:01.610 --> 00:01:04.640
But if I can connect it to a network and
talk to other computers, and

23
00:01:04.640 --> 00:01:07.110
the world wide web,
that's even better, right?

24
00:01:07.110 --> 00:01:08.800
That's really what we want to do.

25
00:01:08.800 --> 00:01:13.180
And when we're having trouble connecting
to our home network, to that work network,

26
00:01:13.180 --> 00:01:15.540
to the Internet,
that's when it can get frustrating.

27
00:01:15.540 --> 00:01:17.220
But with the help of Ronnie Wong here,

28
00:01:17.220 --> 00:01:20.610
we're gonna learn these troubleshooting
methodologies that we can use

00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.100
to figure out what the problem is and
probably fix it.

30
00:01:23.100 --> 00:01:24.980
>> Well yeah,
when we start to take a look at it,

31
00:01:24.980 --> 00:01:27.170
it's not just Ronnie Wong

00:01:27.170 --> 00:01:29.810
But a lot of times it's just

00:01:29.810 --> 00:01:33.630
a company who's been effectively doing
the troubleshooting they've needed to.

34
00:01:33.630 --> 00:01:36.160
And they tend to follow some
troubleshooting methodology.

35
00:01:36.160 --> 00:01:40.790
And when we start talking about that,
they do it for a purpose and for a reason.

36
00:01:40.790 --> 00:01:42.740
And this is something that
we've got to get used to,

37
00:01:42.740 --> 00:01:44.440
if we're working in that scenario.

38
00:01:44.440 --> 00:01:47.790
And the reason for it is,
it's probably been effective in the past.

39
00:01:47.790 --> 00:01:49.910
And what they don't want you doing as now,

40
00:01:49.910 --> 00:01:54.380
their Windows 7 support technician is to
say, look I know a better way to do it.

41
00:01:54.380 --> 00:01:55.120
Don't get me wrong.

42
00:01:55.120 --> 00:01:59.260
You may know it but their way is proven,
it's actually repeatable, and

00:01:59.260 --> 00:02:00.540
they know that it works.

44
00:02:00.540 --> 00:02:02.460
So even though you might
have a better methodology,

45
00:02:02.460 --> 00:02:03.970
that you might want to introduce.

46
00:02:03.970 --> 00:02:05.030
At this point,

47
00:02:05.030 --> 00:02:08.360
you do want to follow their particular
methodology that they are going to follow.

48
00:02:08.360 --> 00:02:11.320
Now, everybody has a way of
actually doing troubleshooting.

49
00:02:11.320 --> 00:02:14.190
And every time you talk to somebody else,
they're like, oh no, this is the way you

00:02:14.190 --> 00:02:16.540
should do that and you're like,
well this is the way I learned it.

51
00:02:16.540 --> 00:02:18.310
I don't know if I should
deviate from that.

52
00:02:18.310 --> 00:02:21.448
Well you actually see that depending
on whatever company you work for,

53
00:02:21.448 --> 00:02:23.181
it may be very diverse, and it may not.

54
00:02:23.181 --> 00:02:27.488
But one of the skills we have to develop
at the very beginning is what we call

55
00:02:27.488 --> 00:02:29.650
determining the scope of the issue.

56
00:02:29.650 --> 00:02:33.570
And when we start talking about that
a lot of the times, it is a little bit

57
00:02:33.570 --> 00:02:38.080
daunting to actually figure out how
widespread a network issue can go.

58
00:02:38.080 --> 00:02:41.350
Well, remember that we have
several different scopes, right?

59
00:02:41.350 --> 00:02:44.030
The very fact is it can be
limited to my computer and

60
00:02:44.030 --> 00:02:49.050
that would be awesome in an enterprise
environment, it was limited to one user.

61
00:02:49.050 --> 00:02:51.670
Not a lot of times is that
always going to be the issue but

62
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:54.330
it would be awesome if we could
determine that right then.

63
00:02:54.330 --> 00:02:58.690
But sometimes Mike, it actually is,
well, beyond that one user right?

64
00:02:58.690 --> 00:03:00.660
>> Yeah, but it's very important
that we determine that,

65
00:03:00.660 --> 00:03:04.770
because that's gonna really guide us into
our next phase of the troubleshooting.

66
00:03:04.770 --> 00:03:07.580
If you're looking at a machine and
it's having problem

67
00:03:07.580 --> 00:03:11.520
if it's just that one machine,
you can focus your efforts there, right?

68
00:03:11.520 --> 00:03:14.800
You can look at it, Ronnie's gonna talk
about all kinds of things, but like I say,

69
00:03:14.800 --> 00:03:18.930
look at the network adaptor, or the cable,
or something wrong with that machine.

70
00:03:18.930 --> 00:03:23.570
But if the same problem is hitting three,
or four, or five people in the office.

71
00:03:23.570 --> 00:03:24.910
That changes the scope right?

72
00:03:24.910 --> 00:03:26.840
Now it's something that's affecting
everybody in the office so

73
00:03:26.840 --> 00:03:29.910
it's probably not an an individual
machine, now we're looking in like

74
00:03:29.910 --> 00:03:33.240
server closets and switches and
routers and things like that.

75
00:03:33.240 --> 00:03:35.810
But wait, what if it's that other
branch office over there too?

76
00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:38.540
So now I'm talking about
two geographic locations,

77
00:03:38.540 --> 00:03:41.700
the problem is not gonna be
the network adaptor on this machine.

78
00:03:41.700 --> 00:03:45.010
So determining that scope is
really an important first step so

79
00:03:45.010 --> 00:03:48.810
we can figure out where our
troubleshooting needs to be done.

80
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:51.300
>> Isolating that issue
is really what the idea

81
00:03:51.300 --> 00:03:53.530
is when we talk about limiting that scope.

82
00:03:53.530 --> 00:03:55.840
Because if we just try to determine
just from this one machine,

83
00:03:55.840 --> 00:03:59.340
oh no this one machine is fine and
I walk away, and

84
00:03:59.340 --> 00:04:02.900
now all of a sudden it's actually
issues in the entire office.

85
00:04:02.900 --> 00:04:05.700
Then there's actually some other
issue that we have to deal with.

86
00:04:05.700 --> 00:04:08.340
So remember that that's what we
want to be able to determine

87
00:04:08.340 --> 00:04:09.620
when we start doing that.

88
00:04:09.620 --> 00:04:11.630
Now when that starts happening,
well, what can you do?

89
00:04:11.630 --> 00:04:14.430
You can start off on
an individual machine and

90
00:04:14.430 --> 00:04:17.180
what Mike mentioned is very important for
us, and

91
00:04:17.180 --> 00:04:21.130
we are trying to determine the scope and
may actually be at the very beginning.

92
00:04:21.130 --> 00:04:24.160
You try and figure out is there something
wrong with that one single machine.

93
00:04:24.160 --> 00:04:25.370
And when we do that,

94
00:04:25.370 --> 00:04:30.110
especially with networking, what we're now
focusing in on is the network adaptor.

95
00:04:30.110 --> 00:04:34.430
So, in other words, the physical adaptor
that's on that computer and connecting in.

96
00:04:34.430 --> 00:04:38.550
As well as the configuration that
can be done on that machine as well.

97
00:04:38.550 --> 00:04:42.990
So we do want to determine if both of
those are actually set up and ready to go.

98
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:47.490
well the network adaptor is fairly easy to
determine whether or not that's the issue.

99
00:04:47.490 --> 00:04:49.500
And you can look at it in two ways, right?

100
00:04:49.500 --> 00:04:52.270
There's going to be a logical
configuration on it, there's going

101
00:04:52.270 --> 00:04:56.100
to be a physical way that the thing
should actually show us if it's working.

102
00:04:56.100 --> 00:04:58.750
And I know this sounds like baby-steps.

103
