00:27:30.640 --> 00:27:34.130
I go, yeah let's just reimage it and
start all over, and we're fine.

557
00:27:34.130 --> 00:27:36.230
>> Yeah, corporate environments nowadays,

558
00:27:36.230 --> 00:27:40.250
we focus on making sure that users are
storing their data either on our servers,

559
00:27:40.250 --> 00:27:42.620
on our network, or even out in the cloud.

560
00:27:42.620 --> 00:27:46.840
Nothing is stored locally on that
machine for that very reason.

561
00:27:46.840 --> 00:27:49.790
If we get infected,
if something's going wrong,

562
00:27:49.790 --> 00:27:55.020
I can simply reimage that machine,
you log back on.

563
00:27:55.020 --> 00:27:57.795
We probably have policies and
other systems in place,

564
00:27:57.795 --> 00:28:01.416
like System Center, Configuration Manager
and Operations Manager,

565
00:28:01.416 --> 00:28:03.670
to reinstall all the applications.

566
00:28:03.670 --> 00:28:05.545
And if I can get all that
done in 45 minutes and

567
00:28:05.545 --> 00:28:09.530
that user can be productive again, that's
definitely the way that we wanna go.

568
00:28:09.530 --> 00:28:11.820
But, as Ronnie said,
we don't jump to that.

569
00:28:11.820 --> 00:28:16.424
We should definitely try to do a little
troubleshooting and fix it first.

570
00:28:16.424 --> 00:28:20.674
Cuz I'll tell you, even though you've got
policies in place that say nothing gets

571
00:28:20.674 --> 00:28:24.630
stored, if that's important,
do not store it on your local machine.

572
00:28:24.630 --> 00:28:28.010
We'll redirect through My Documents and
all of that good stuff.

573
00:28:28.010 --> 00:28:31.200
We'll give them access to
OneDrive through Microsoft or

574
00:28:31.200 --> 00:28:33.200
whatever cloud provider we're using.

575
00:28:33.200 --> 00:28:36.900
We do everything we can, and
I guarantee you, you reimage that machine,

576
00:28:36.900 --> 00:28:40.797
that user is gonna come back to you and
say, what happened to that TPS report?

577
00:28:40.797 --> 00:28:42.503
I was working on it all day long and
now it's gone.

578
00:28:42.503 --> 00:28:46.120
And you're like, are you kidding me,
you had it on your local machine?

579
00:28:46.120 --> 00:28:47.520
That was the only copy?

580
00:28:47.520 --> 00:28:52.630
And, yeah, so it has to be a last
resort in most situations.

581
00:28:52.630 --> 00:28:56.360
>> Yeah, and if it's not, well that's
actually the responsibility of that user.

582
00:28:56.360 --> 00:29:00.434
But, yes, this should not be our first
resort, even though we, I hate to say it,

583
00:29:00.434 --> 00:29:02.100
it's always been my go to [LAUGH].

584
00:29:02.100 --> 00:29:06.076
In the end, I am the worst at this cuz I
just get frustrated after a while, but

585
00:29:06.076 --> 00:29:08.320
that's what you're there for, right?

586
00:29:08.320 --> 00:29:11.960
You are there to figure out the puzzle,
and so you might as well take the time to

587
00:29:11.960 --> 00:29:14.030
do it in whatever time
limit they give you, right?

588
00:29:14.030 --> 00:29:17.040
Once they tell you, if it's 30 minutes or
an hour, take that time and

589
00:29:17.040 --> 00:29:18.820
make the most effective use of it.

590
00:29:18.820 --> 00:29:22.077
At that point, if you don't,
you'll probably see that that's usually

591
00:29:22.077 --> 00:29:25.017
the resort that you go to,
which is in 30 minutes here or an hour,

592
00:29:25.017 --> 00:29:28.503
if you can't fix it, just reimage it and
let's start all over and keep going.

593
00:29:28.503 --> 00:29:32.660
And you do have to deal with that,
that's just the nature of that business.

594
00:29:32.660 --> 00:29:37.090
But just remember, the applications,
they're not going away, so you can't

595
00:29:37.090 --> 00:29:40.780
hope that that's ever gonna happen,
so you do have an effective way here.

596
00:29:40.780 --> 00:29:42.156
At least some of
the different methodologies,

597
00:29:42.156 --> 00:29:45.295
some of the different things you can look
for when you are talking about having to

598
00:29:45.295 --> 00:29:47.557
troubleshoot the way that
applications end up failing us.

599
00:29:47.557 --> 00:29:50.811
>> All right Ronnie, well again, a lot
of good information, thanks for that.

600
00:29:50.811 --> 00:29:54.437
I feel like we can troubleshoot
applications a little bit better now,

601
00:29:54.437 --> 00:29:57.880
keep my users happy,
keep those applications running.

602
00:29:57.880 --> 00:30:00.260
All right, ladies and gentlemen,
that's gonna do it for this episode,

603
00:30:00.260 --> 00:30:01.780
hope you enjoyed watching.

604
00:30:01.780 --> 00:30:04.640
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

605
00:30:04.640 --> 00:30:05.440
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

606
00:30:05.440 --> 00:30:08.596
>> And we'll see you next time.

607
00:30:08.596 --> 00:30:12.920
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Mike and Ronnie take a look at user logon issues.  The majority of these issues may end user error that technicians need to be able to identify, according to the guys.  They also talk reducing these issues. Using the auditing features found in the event viewer helps to identify issue.s  Also they mention issues that may prevent users from running applications on the computer as well as how the Windows Firewall helps with basic security
episodes.title: User Accounts & Basic Security
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.132
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.132 --> 00:00:13.051
Hello, and welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.051 --> 00:00:14.790
I'm your host, Mike Roderick.

4
00:00:14.790 --> 00:00:17.450
With me today is my friend and
colleague, Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:17.450 --> 00:00:18.360
How you doing, Ronnie?

6
00:00:18.360 --> 00:00:19.132
>> I am doing great.

7
00:00:19.132 --> 00:00:22.620
This is another great day to be right
here in the studio as we continue on

8
00:00:22.620 --> 00:00:25.200
to take a look at supporting Windows 7.

9
00:00:25.200 --> 00:00:29.950
Remember that this is not an exam really
focused type of show that we're doing.

10
00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:33.670
It really is more about trying to say,
hey, we're supporting the enterprise.

11
00:00:33.670 --> 00:00:34.860
We're still running Windows 7.

12
00:00:34.860 --> 00:00:38.280
What are some of those issues
that we need to be aware of and

13
00:00:38.280 --> 00:00:40.290
be able to troubleshoot as well.

14
00:00:40.290 --> 00:00:43.490
And today we're focusing in on,
well, really user accounts and

15
00:00:43.490 --> 00:00:45.354
some basic security issues.

16
00:00:45.354 --> 00:00:49.430
Now, even though we have covered security
in other episodes, these are just kind of

17
00:00:49.430 --> 00:00:52.710
some of the ones that we don't really
think about in terms of security, but

18
00:00:52.710 --> 00:00:55.050
issues that we do address
especially with end users.

19
00:00:55.050 --> 00:00:58.390
And a lot of times just with end users
trying to connect to some place else, too.

20
00:00:58.390 --> 00:01:00.185
>> Yeah, and one of the first
things we're gonna look at,

21
00:01:00.185 --> 00:01:02.450
Ronnie, is good old authentication, right?

22
00:01:02.450 --> 00:01:05.200
And we know that's one of those things
that we get a lot of calls at the help

23
00:01:05.200 --> 00:01:06.850
desk that deal with that problem.

24
00:01:06.850 --> 00:01:11.408
Whether it's my account's not working,
or my password's not working, or

25
00:01:11.408 --> 00:01:14.983
I can't access this resource and
I think I should be able to,

26
00:01:14.983 --> 00:01:20.210
authentication is something we'll spend
a little bit of time on at the help desk.

27
00:01:20.210 --> 00:01:23.250
>> Right, when we start thinking
about this idea with authentication,

28
00:01:23.250 --> 00:01:26.860
the problem happens to be a lot of
times is that users don't understand

29
00:01:26.860 --> 00:01:30.560
when they're authenticating, who they're
presenting their credentials to.

30
00:01:30.560 --> 00:01:32.630
So let me kind of give you a for
instance here.

31
00:01:32.630 --> 00:01:37.320
The very fact is a user's computer may be
presenting their credentials, let's say,

32
00:01:37.320 --> 00:01:41.510
to an Active Directory domain controller
if they're part of an Active Directory.

33
00:01:41.510 --> 00:01:42.390
And that means they're not really

34
00:01:42.390 --> 00:01:44.930
checking the user account
right there on the computer.

35
00:01:44.930 --> 00:01:48.380
But, sometimes, the only place that
they actually are checking, though,

36
00:01:48.380 --> 00:01:51.480
is against that local security
count right there on the computer.

37
00:01:51.480 --> 00:01:54.340
Now, Mike, if I do that, right,

38
00:01:54.340 --> 00:01:56.770
there are some issues that we
really have to face, right?

39
00:01:56.770 --> 00:02:01.680
Let's say that I think I'm gonna get
access to a domain resource, but

40
00:02:01.680 --> 00:02:03.530
I'm logged in as a local user,

41
00:02:03.530 --> 00:02:05.560
I may actually have to deal with
issues like that too, right?

42
00:02:05.560 --> 00:02:06.630
>> Yeah, it's not gonna work.

43
00:02:06.630 --> 00:02:10.860
And you see this in scenarios where maybe
most of our computers are gonna be part of

44
00:02:10.860 --> 00:02:13.750
the domain, and they probably have
an account in Active Directory, and

45
00:02:13.750 --> 00:02:17.600
let's say it's Mike, but we've also made
them a local account on that machine.

46
00:02:17.600 --> 00:02:20.950
Especially laptops where they take
those laptops outside of the domain,

47
00:02:20.950 --> 00:02:23.790
they might have a local account,
as well, that they can log into

48
00:02:23.790 --> 00:02:27.640
that machine with when they're outside,
and it's named Mike, all right?

49
00:02:27.640 --> 00:02:29.550
And so now when I go to log in,

50
00:02:29.550 --> 00:02:33.620
if I'm not paying attention I
could type in the wrong password.

51
00:02:33.620 --> 00:02:37.228
If I do login with that local account
instead of my domain account, and

52
00:02:37.228 --> 00:02:41.190
I'm at work, I'm not gonna have any access
to any network resources because nobody

53
00:02:41.190 --> 00:02:43.900
outside the local machine is
gonna trust that local account.

54
00:02:45.100 --> 00:02:47.800
>> So whenever we start taking a look at
this, it's really important then that

55
00:02:47.800 --> 00:02:51.280
the user understand what context
that they're logging into, or

56
00:02:51.280 --> 00:02:53.840
they might not have access
to those resources.

57
00:02:53.840 --> 00:02:55.750
So let's go ahead and
show you what we're talking about here.

58
00:02:55.750 --> 00:02:58.262
Let me go ahead and
log off of this machine.

59
00:02:58.262 --> 00:02:59.940
All right, so
here we are on this computer.

60
00:02:59.940 --> 00:03:02.540
And what I've done is
I'm at the login screen.

61
00:03:02.540 --> 00:03:06.040
Now that I'm at the login screen, I might
just simply go in and type in my password.

62
00:03:06.040 --> 00:03:08.810
Now a regular user might do this
without ever looking at this

63
00:03:08.810 --> 00:03:13.230
prefix that we see right here
where you see lab02\Ronnie.

64
00:03:13.230 --> 00:03:17.950
I know I've done it several times where
I've been on a machine, in a domain, and

65
00:03:17.950 --> 00:03:22.000
it actually kicked me out and I was doing
something as local administrator and said,

66
00:03:22.000 --> 00:03:23.300
all right, I'm done.

67
00:03:23.300 --> 00:03:26.920
And then I log out, and
I just quickly type my password back in,

68
00:03:26.920 --> 00:03:29.820
I try to gain access to that network
resource, and it doesn't work.

69
00:03:29.820 --> 00:03:32.170
So that's exactly what can happen.

70
00:03:32.170 --> 00:03:33.750
So we end up logging in.

71
00:03:33.750 --> 00:03:38.750
The user now thinks that he's logged in,
just like he was as a regular domain user,

72
00:03:38.750 --> 00:03:42.760
but now he can't gain access,
maybe, to those network resources.

73
00:03:42.760 --> 00:03:45.210
And so
that's where the frustration comes in.

74
00:03:45.210 --> 00:03:47.570
>> Yeah, cuz, as you said,
they're logged in, and

75
00:03:47.570 --> 00:03:51.460
they go to connect to that file server,
or whatever the case may be, and

76
00:03:51.460 --> 00:03:54.170
all of a sudden they cannot,
and they don't understand why.

77
00:03:54.170 --> 00:03:57.470
They don't know the difference between
a local account and a domain account.

78
00:03:57.470 --> 00:03:59.140
And as you said, they don't pay attention.

79
00:03:59.140 --> 00:04:02.530
They just see the password dialog box,
they type it in, and they go.

80
00:04:02.530 --> 00:04:06.360
>> So let's go ahead and show you what
we should be able to help the user do.

81
00:04:06.360 --> 00:04:07.740
And I know that this sounds simple, but

82
00:04:07.740 --> 00:04:10.400
it is something that they really
need to pay attention to.

83
00:04:10.400 --> 00:04:11.660
So I'm simply going to log out again.

84
00:04:11.660 --> 00:04:15.600
So gonna go ahead and click on the Start
button, and to the right of the Shut Down,

85
00:04:15.600 --> 00:04:17.720
select Log Off.

86
00:04:17.720 --> 00:04:20.890
So I'm getting to the new terminology
of this as a sign out, sign off, or

87
00:04:20.890 --> 00:04:22.020
whatever it might be.

88
00:04:22.020 --> 00:04:24.380
So here it is, Ctrl+Alt+Delete.

89
00:04:24.380 --> 00:04:27.690
And now, what we need to do is tell
the user to, look, you gotta slow down.

90
00:04:27.690 --> 00:04:30.700
If you're not getting access to network
resources and you once were and

91
00:04:30.700 --> 00:04:34.540
nothing has changed on your computer,
let's take a look at the username.

92
00:04:34.540 --> 00:04:37.170
Now, they may say, all right,
I think everything looks good,

93
00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:38.570
there's my name right there.

94
00:04:38.570 --> 00:04:41.620
What you want to do is tell them
to go ahead and Switch User.

95
00:04:41.620 --> 00:04:44.930
And when they do that,
then you can select Other User.

96
00:04:44.930 --> 00:04:48.540
At this point, normally what we do is kind
of that, oh, we call it the pre-2000 name,

97
00:04:48.540 --> 00:04:50.450
is that what we call it?

98
00:04:50.450 --> 00:04:51.760
>> Yeah, the pre-Windows 2000?

99
00:04:51.760 --> 00:04:55.610
>> Yeah, so I normally tell them to
go ahead and type in the word, lab.

100
00:04:55.610 --> 00:04:56.730
Now, I don't have to.

101
00:04:56.730 --> 00:04:59.330
If you take a look right down here
underneath where it says the word

102
00:04:59.330 --> 00:05:01.500
password, I know it's a little
bit difficult to see,

103
00:05:01.500 --> 00:05:05.780
it does tell me the name of my domain
right here that I am logging onto it.

104
00:05:05.780 --> 00:05:08.965
But if I want to make sure, and
this is what I've always done,

105
00:05:08.965 --> 00:05:13.650
is I just type in lab\, and
now I can actually enter in

106
00:05:13.650 --> 00:05:19.220
the exact same name which is is
identical at this point here.

107
00:05:19.220 --> 00:05:24.130
And now I start to log in, and
then I should be logged in with my own

108
00:05:24.130 --> 00:05:26.910
network profile or
my domain profile at this point.

109
00:05:26.910 --> 00:05:29.640
And if the user account's been there for
a long time, well,

110
00:05:29.640 --> 00:05:31.790
they should get access
to all of their files.

111
00:05:31.790 --> 00:05:33.530
And actually,
I didn't think about that, Mike.

112
00:05:33.530 --> 00:05:37.530
The other thing that most users actually
do complain about is that they go, Ronnie,

113
00:05:37.530 --> 00:05:40.560
I logged in, but
My Documents folder was clear.

114
00:05:40.560 --> 00:05:41.389
>> It was empty.
>> I was thinking about

115
00:05:41.389 --> 00:05:41.942
that yeah, it was empty.

116
00:05:41.942 --> 00:05:43.405
>> [LAUGH]
>> Where the heck is all my stuff?

117
00:05:43.405 --> 00:05:45.770
And again, they've logged on
with a different profile, right?

118
00:05:45.770 --> 00:05:48.030
They've got their domain account and
their local account.

119
00:05:48.030 --> 00:05:50.120
Well, those are gonna be
two separate profiles,

120
00:05:50.120 --> 00:05:54.820
which means two separate My Documents,
My Pictures, and all that good stuff.

121
00:05:54.820 --> 00:05:57.452
And if we can go back to that logon
screen just for a second, Ronnie.

122
00:05:57.452 --> 00:05:58.764
>> Sure.
>> As Ronnie mentioned,

123
00:05:58.764 --> 00:06:00.890
that's the pre-Windows 2000 name.

124
00:06:00.890 --> 00:06:05.600
The name of the domain was right
underneath there, so you could always just

125
00:06:05.600 --> 00:06:11.240
type your name, and the domain part
is assumed, so you could do that.

126
00:06:11.240 --> 00:06:14.350
You could also use what
we call your UPN suffix.

127
00:06:14.350 --> 00:06:17.240
And in Force where there's many,
many domains,

128
00:06:17.240 --> 00:06:18.460
this might be something that we do.

129
00:06:18.460 --> 00:06:22.160
It might be Ronnie@lab.net, or whatever.

130
00:06:22.160 --> 00:06:25.080
That would also work, so
if you went that way.

131
00:06:25.080 --> 00:06:26.030
Same account,

132
00:06:26.030 --> 00:06:30.870
two different ways to specify that
you're logging in with a domain account.

133
00:06:30.870 --> 00:06:34.730
As you do the either domain \ username, or

134
00:06:34.730 --> 00:06:38.070
username @ domain, and
then the same password.

135
00:06:38.070 --> 00:06:39.930
And another cool thing you
can do from this dialogue is,

136
00:06:39.930 --> 00:06:43.830
and this is something I find
very useful as a technician,

137
00:06:43.830 --> 00:06:47.900
is I go to a machine and
I can't log on to the domain, right?

138
00:06:47.900 --> 00:06:52.940
And so I need to log on to the local
machine as that local administrator, but

139
00:06:52.940 --> 00:06:55.910
I don't know the name of the machine
to put out there in front.

140
00:06:55.910 --> 00:07:01.100
So if you do a .\, you'll see
that where it says log on to lab

141
00:07:01.100 --> 00:07:03.820
actually changes to
the name of the machine.

142
00:07:03.820 --> 00:07:06.180
And so a quick,
dirty way to log on with a local account,

143
00:07:06.180 --> 00:07:10.030
if the name of the machine is long,
you can just do .\Ronnie.

144
00:07:10.030 --> 00:07:11.920
Or if you don't know
the name of the machine,

145
00:07:11.920 --> 00:07:14.990
that backslash will show you the name
of that machine from the log on screen.

146
00:07:14.990 --> 00:07:17.740
>> Yeah, and those are great little
tips because there's no doubt that

147
00:07:17.740 --> 00:07:20.890
even though I think I know what the name
of every machine on my network is,

148
00:07:20.890 --> 00:07:22.050
there's a chance.

149
00:07:22.050 --> 00:07:26.430
And we've had this happen, where somebody
just moves computers around just to see,

150
00:07:26.430 --> 00:07:30.190
well, this computer will work for you
right now, and since you're using a domain

151
00:07:30.190 --> 00:07:33.300
account, it shouldn't matter
what computer you're really on.

152
00:07:33.300 --> 00:07:36.040
So that way they just move it to test it
out and then they forget because like, oh,

153
00:07:36.040 --> 00:07:37.920
it's working, just use that one for now.

154
00:07:37.920 --> 00:07:39.350
And they forget to put it back, and

155
00:07:39.350 --> 00:07:42.040
all of a sudden you go, okay,
this is supposed to be computer 13.

156
00:07:42.040 --> 00:07:45.850
It's not computer 13, and you keep
typing in lab 13, or whatever it is, and

157
00:07:45.850 --> 00:07:47.200
it's not working for you.

158
00:07:47.200 --> 00:07:48.250
Very easy mistakes.

159
00:07:48.250 --> 00:07:50.120
>> Yeah, large environments,
working in help desk.

160
00:07:50.120 --> 00:07:52.272
I've been in situations
where I need to remote in.

161
00:07:52.272 --> 00:07:56.342
This user's called me up and said, hey,
I need you to help me fix my machine.

162
00:07:56.342 --> 00:07:58.676
Sure, I'll remote into it,
what's the name of your machine?

163
00:07:58.676 --> 00:07:59.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't know,

164
00:07:59.800 --> 00:08:03.343
I just sit at this thing every day, but

And in a moment, you actually see it
looks really just about identical

615
00:29:43.550 --> 00:29:47.800
to what you can actually set up, those
inbound rules, outbound rules, as well as

616
00:29:47.800 --> 00:29:51.860
connection security rules if you needed
those, that type of granularity.

617
00:29:51.860 --> 00:29:55.940
So we can set this domain wide if we
need to, or just certain scoped groups

618
00:29:55.940 --> 00:29:58.910
Inside of our domain, you name it,
we can control it that way.

619
00:29:58.910 --> 00:30:02.090
And that way, people don't just go, you
know what I'm gonna do, just to test it?

620
00:30:02.090 --> 00:30:03.800
I'm gonna turn the firewall off.

621
00:30:03.800 --> 00:30:06.580
We can instead lock it
down this way as well.

622
00:30:06.580 --> 00:30:08.540
So there's a lot of control that you have.

623
00:30:08.540 --> 00:30:11.830
But you do have to actually
make sure that you understand

624
00:30:11.830 --> 00:30:15.400
what programs need to be going through
your firewall, and which ones don't.

625
00:30:15.400 --> 00:30:16.690
Cuz if you block one by accident,

626
00:30:16.690 --> 00:30:19.110
people are gonna have a hard
day doing their jobs.

627
00:30:19.110 --> 00:30:19.970
>> All right Ronnie.

628
00:30:19.970 --> 00:30:21.490
Very good,
a lot of great information there.

629
00:30:21.490 --> 00:30:25.900
Keeping our machines safe and being able
to help our users troubleshoot issues

630
00:30:25.900 --> 00:30:30.640
with accounts, accessing resources,
and good old firewalls.

631
00:30:30.640 --> 00:30:31.580
So great job, Ronnie.

632
00:30:31.580 --> 00:30:32.960
Appreciate that.

633
00:30:32.960 --> 00:30:35.030
But for this episode that is gonna do it.

634
00:30:35.030 --> 00:30:38.170
So signing off for
ITProTV I'm Mike Roderick.

635
00:30:38.170 --> 00:30:38.980
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

636
00:30:38.980 --> 00:30:41.735
>> And we'll see you next time.

637
00:30:41.735 --> 00:30:45.960
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike take a look at some of the hardware issues that end users often mention.  They take a look at managing drivers. They also mention that memory issues can be problematic and talk about the memory diagnostic tool that can help identify a problem module and they take a look at disk management tools and the use of diskpart to help when adding additional drives for use.
episodes.title: Hardware Related Issues
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.087 --> 00:00:10.045
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.045 --> 00:00:13.047
Hello, and welcome to another
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.047 --> 00:00:14.785
I'm your host Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:14.785 --> 00:00:16.645
With me today is Mr. Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:16.645 --> 00:00:17.545
How you doing, Ronnie?

6
00:00:17.545 --> 00:00:18.495
>> I'm doing great today.

7
00:00:18.495 --> 00:00:22.515
It's another great day to be right here,
as we take a look at supporting Windows 7.

8
00:00:22.515 --> 00:00:24.825
Remember that this is not
an exam-centric type of show.

9
00:00:24.825 --> 00:00:26.505
What we're trying to do, of course,

10
00:00:26.505 --> 00:00:30.685
is talk about some of the issues that we
face, as well network support technicians

11
00:00:30.685 --> 00:00:33.955
a lot of times,
as well as enterprise administrators too.

12
00:00:33.955 --> 00:00:37.110
Making sure that we understand that,
a lot of stuff even though it's covered on

13
00:00:37.110 --> 00:00:41.070
the exam and that's good material, there's
a lot of things that we just have to

14
00:00:41.070 --> 00:00:44.820
be aware of, and we need to learn how and
be able to troubleshoot as well.

15
00:00:44.820 --> 00:00:48.370
And today we need to focus in a little
bit on hardware troubleshooting,

16
00:00:48.370 --> 00:00:49.350
is what we need to do.

17
00:00:49.350 --> 00:00:50.090
>> Always fun.

18
00:00:50.090 --> 00:00:52.050
Yeah, something that
we're gonna have to do.

19
00:00:52.050 --> 00:00:53.960
We're gonna have hardware
that gives us issues.

20
00:00:53.960 --> 00:00:55.580
Our users are gonna call us up.

21
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:57.070
And we gotta be able to fix these things.

22
00:00:57.070 --> 00:00:59.120
So one of the first things
I think we wanna look at,

23
00:00:59.120 --> 00:01:02.500
Ronnie, is probably drivers,
cuz that's really where it all starts.

24
00:01:02.500 --> 00:01:07.090
I can't use that piece of hardware until
my computer knows how to talk to it.

25
00:01:07.090 --> 00:01:08.110
>> That's exactly right.

26
00:01:08.110 --> 00:01:12.750
Whenever we start talking about the driver
issues that are out there, it is

27
00:01:12.750 --> 00:01:16.550
the driver that becomes the translator
between our operating system and

28
00:01:16.550 --> 00:01:20.520
the hardware that we install into
that operating system as well.

29
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:25.590
Now drivers usually are going to be
developed by the hardware vendor, and

30
00:01:25.590 --> 00:01:28.040
so this is where we end up getting issues.

31
00:01:28.040 --> 00:01:29.510
A lot of times when they develop it,

32
00:01:29.510 --> 00:01:32.950
it could be that they develop it to
actually work perfectly with Windows.

33
00:01:32.950 --> 00:01:34.750
But sometimes they
develop it independently,

34
00:01:34.750 --> 00:01:37.340
saying well it probably
works with Windows,

35
00:01:37.340 --> 00:01:41.850
but it may not work with Windows,
and we have issues that may come up.

36
00:01:41.850 --> 00:01:43.960
Now, this has happened to me.

37
00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:47.470
Right now as I've actually
gone to the Mac Book,

38
00:01:47.470 --> 00:01:50.750
I had a USB docking station designed for
Windows.

39
00:01:50.750 --> 00:01:52.590
And I'm having a driver issue because,

40
00:01:52.590 --> 00:01:55.930
well, even though that device was
actually designed for Windows,

41
00:01:55.930 --> 00:02:01.260
somebody's actually tried to take the
driver and make it work inside of Mac OS.

42
00:02:01.260 --> 00:02:04.230
And so at that point here,
the driver may work and it may not.

43
00:02:04.230 --> 00:02:06.290
Now, you might be going, Ronnie,
we're talking about Windows,

44
00:02:06.290 --> 00:02:08.490
why the heck are you bringing in Mac?

45
00:02:08.490 --> 00:02:11.660
Well, because inside of Windows,
we can have drivers that

46
00:02:11.660 --> 00:02:15.340
we actually get installed on our
computers that do the same thing.

47
00:02:15.340 --> 00:02:19.590
And one of the things that Windows
has tried to do over the years

48
00:02:19.590 --> 00:02:24.580
is to prevent issues like this by
requiring the drivers to be signed.

49
00:02:24.580 --> 00:02:28.050
Digitally signed so that they actually
say look, this is checked out,

50
00:02:28.050 --> 00:02:31.120
we believe the code in this
driver will work perfectly fine.

51
00:02:31.120 --> 00:02:36.210
And even then a lot of those drivers are
also packaged inside of Windows too, so

52
00:02:36.210 --> 00:02:39.190
we don't have to worry about going out and
hunting down drivers a lot of times.

53
00:02:39.190 --> 00:02:42.370
>> Yeah, Windows comes with
a very large driver.cab file,

54
00:02:42.370 --> 00:02:43.930
if they still call it that.

55
00:02:43.930 --> 00:02:44.440
I think they do.

56
00:02:44.440 --> 00:02:46.700
And that's basically what Ronnie said.

57
00:02:46.700 --> 00:02:50.800
It's just a library of drivers, and so
just about any device you plug into

58
00:02:50.800 --> 00:02:54.860
your Windows operating system, it's gonna
at least recognize and be able to use.

59
00:02:54.860 --> 00:02:58.220
That doesn't mean we don't wanna go
out and get another driver for it.

60
00:02:58.220 --> 00:03:01.310
All right,
that's a generic driver built by Windows.

61
00:03:01.310 --> 00:03:04.985
Good thing to do would be go to
manufacturer and get their latest driver,

62
00:03:04.985 --> 00:03:07.005
right, the people that made the device.

63
00:03:07.005 --> 00:03:11.475
Sometimes those generic drivers will let
you communicate with a piece of hardware,

64
00:03:11.475 --> 00:03:13.935
but won't let you take
advantage of all the features.

65
00:03:13.935 --> 00:03:17.695
I know graphics cards are a big one where
you've got a driver in Windows that you

66
00:03:17.695 --> 00:03:23.490
buy that nice ATI Radeon or
whatever the latest graphics card is,

67
00:03:23.490 --> 00:03:26.140
and Windows recognizes it and
allows you to use it.

68
00:03:26.140 --> 00:03:30.010
But if you go out there and
get that driver from ATI or from Nvidia or

69
00:03:30.010 --> 00:03:33.230
whomever, now all of a sudden you
get this great little interface and

70
00:03:33.230 --> 00:03:37.840
you can start controlling color spectrums,
I mean everything, right?

71
00:03:37.840 --> 00:03:41.750
So sometimes even though Windows has
a driver, we still might want to go obtain

72
00:03:41.750 --> 00:03:44.980
the driver from the manufacturer or
the one that came on the media.

73
00:03:44.980 --> 00:03:48.100
>> And that's actually one of the best
things that we can do, right?

74
00:03:48.100 --> 00:03:50.690
That basic installation is
really about functionality.

75
00:03:50.690 --> 00:03:52.130
The only thing that Windows cares about,
right,

76
00:03:52.130 --> 00:03:55.150
is that code works inside of Windows.

77
00:03:55.150 --> 00:03:57.680
And so, they don't tend to actually
install all those additional

78
00:03:57.680 --> 00:03:59.480
features that Mike was talking about.

79
00:03:59.480 --> 00:04:03.870
The manufacturer of that device wants you
to use all the features that are available

80
00:04:03.870 --> 00:04:06.800
because they believe that that's gonna
actually make you a loyal customer, and

81
00:04:06.800 --> 00:04:09.060
you coming back to that product too.

82
00:04:09.060 --> 00:04:11.040
So when you do have these drivers, and

83
00:04:11.040 --> 00:04:14.190
you think about one of the issues
that you will face a lot of times.

84
00:04:14.190 --> 00:04:17.980
I think of webcams more often than not,
cuz those are the ones I've dealt with for

85
00:04:17.980 --> 00:04:21.710
the last few years, is that
sometimes they work perfectly fine.

86
00:04:21.710 --> 00:04:23.030
You know it turns on, it turns off.

87
00:04:23.030 --> 00:04:26.293
But then when somebody says no you
can take that webcam and zoom it, or

88
00:04:26.293 --> 00:04:29.462
you can actually add the little
flaming hat or head whatever it is.

89
00:04:29.462 --> 00:04:34.003
I don't see that feature or option,
was always go out to that website and

90
00:04:34.003 --> 00:04:38.254
make sure you download the latest
driver and install that on there.

91
00:04:38.254 --> 00:04:40.086
And then, yes, you do get those features.

92
00:04:40.086 --> 00:04:41.939
So having the correct driver and

93
00:04:41.939 --> 00:04:46.370
a lot of times the most up-to-date
driver is what helps you out there.

94
00:04:46.370 --> 00:04:48.030
Sometimes, even if you're
missing something or

95
00:04:48.030 --> 00:04:50.290
it's not working perfecting fine,
updating it will help, too.

96
00:04:50.290 --> 00:04:52.050
>> Yeah, reinstalling it or updating it.

97
00:04:52.050 --> 00:04:55.430
One of the common mistakes we
make is buying a device, and

98
00:04:55.430 --> 00:04:59.300
in that box came a DVD or
CD with the driver on it.

99
00:04:59.300 --> 00:05:02.060
We assume that that's the latest driver.

100
00:05:02.060 --> 00:05:04.140
But, if we think about
the manufacturing process and

101
00:05:04.140 --> 00:05:09.230
things like that, that box could have been
packed up months ago, shipped overseas,

102
00:05:09.230 --> 00:05:13.480
sit on a shelf in a store somewhere before
you actually went and picked it up.

103
00:05:13.480 --> 00:05:16.730
So, the driver's already months old and
there could have been a security

104
00:05:16.730 --> 00:05:21.668
update that's come out for that, or
a functionality addition, or fix.

105
00:05:21.668 --> 00:05:25.910
So, install the device, use that
driver that came on the media, and

106
00:05:25.910 --> 00:05:27.930
then turn around and
go out to the manufacturers website,

107
00:05:27.930 --> 00:05:31.320
and make sure that you do have the latest
driver, any updates that are available.

108
00:05:31.320 --> 00:05:34.230
>> There's no doubt that this
is kind of the pattern that

109
00:05:34.230 --> 00:05:35.750
you normally end up seeing.

110
00:05:35.750 --> 00:05:39.420
But even today it's actually
become more automatic for us.

111
00:05:39.420 --> 00:05:42.960
The last printer I bought, and that was
still I'm gonna say a few years ago.

112
00:05:42.960 --> 00:05:44.790
I didn't even have to download a driver,
Mike.

113
00:05:44.790 --> 00:05:49.175
Automatically when we plugged that thing
in and the machine recognized it, it told

114
00:05:49.175 --> 00:05:53.785
me, it was like hey, this particular
whatever number, 3510 I think is what it

115
00:05:53.785 --> 00:05:58.395
was, says would like to go out to HP's
website and download the latest driver.

116
00:05:58.395 --> 00:06:03.535
So, I didn't even have to say, I need
to and check if there's a newer driver.

117
00:06:03.535 --> 00:06:07.615
That device plugged into the network,
it automatically knew it was plugged in,

118
00:06:07.615 --> 00:06:09.475
it automatically knew
that it had to go and

119
00:06:09.475 --> 00:06:13.130
check for the latest driver to
download and install as well.

120
00:06:13.130 --> 00:06:17.150
So it's kind of almost
spooky in the background.

121
00:06:17.150 --> 00:06:19.860
Because now you don't realize what's
actually getting turned on on your

122
00:06:19.860 --> 00:06:22.620
machines what they're plugging in,
and what they're installing, and

123
00:06:22.620 --> 00:06:23.920
what they're leaving on.

124
00:06:23.920 --> 00:06:26.930
But having these up-to-date
drivers are very important.

125
00:06:26.930 --> 00:06:29.700
Sometimes updating
drivers can cause issues.

126
00:06:29.700 --> 00:06:32.140
And that's what we also
have to deal with as well.

127
00:06:32.140 --> 00:06:34.220
So the good thing is we
can show you about that,

128
00:06:34.220 --> 00:06:36.960
and even when you actually have
to deal with driver problems.

129
00:06:36.960 --> 00:06:38.040
And so let's go ahead and do that,

130
00:06:38.040 --> 00:06:42.360
we wanna go into that place that we call
the device manager is where we wanna head.

131
00:06:42.360 --> 00:06:46.360
So here it is on Windows 7,
couple of ways we can get to it, but

132
00:06:46.360 --> 00:06:51.260
if I go ahead and select the start button,
I like to right click on computer, and

133
00:06:51.260 --> 00:06:52.940
go to manage, is what I like to do.

134
00:06:52.940 --> 00:06:55.840
And that brings up the computer
management console.

135
00:06:55.840 --> 00:06:58.100
And inside the computer
management console,

136
00:06:58.100 --> 00:07:00.490
there's the device driver
listed right there.

137
00:07:00.490 --> 00:07:03.180
And this is what we're
normally looking for.

138
00:07:03.180 --> 00:07:07.530
Usually, if you do see other symbols right
here at this particular point in time,

139
00:07:07.530 --> 00:07:11.660
like a yellow symbol,
that normally is an indicator, that hey,

140
00:07:11.660 --> 00:07:14.610
drivers probably missing or
you know somethings wrong.

141
00:07:14.610 --> 00:07:16.010
I'm not talking to that device.

142
00:07:16.010 --> 00:07:19.310
It says I see it, but there's no way
I can communicate with that device.

143
00:07:19.310 --> 00:07:21.910
And I'm seeing that over time on several

144
00:07:21.910 --> 00:07:24.960
of these different options that
you see right here before you.

145
00:07:24.960 --> 00:07:27.770
So what you can actually
end up doing then,

146
00:07:27.770 --> 00:07:31.990
if you do have some device like that,
well what ends up happening.

147
00:07:31.990 --> 00:07:33.130
So let's see what we're gonna do.

148
00:07:33.130 --> 00:07:34.690
Let's do this mouse here.

149
00:07:34.690 --> 00:07:39.130
And you see where it's actually
the VMware pointing device at this point.

150
00:07:39.130 --> 00:07:41.120
So there's a couple of things, right?

151
00:07:41.120 --> 00:07:43.410
If you go,
I don't know how old this driver is,

152
00:07:43.410 --> 00:07:45.490
you can possibly update this driver.

153
00:07:45.490 --> 00:07:48.916
And this is where you would go out and
try and find that manufacturer's driver.

154
00:07:48.916 --> 00:07:51.872
Now, that's actually not something
I wanna do on this one, but

155
00:07:51.872 --> 00:07:54.791
let's say it was a Logitech mouse,
or whatever it is, right?

156
00:07:54.791 --> 00:07:59.162
You go out and you download that And now
all of the sudden the left pinky button

157
00:07:59.162 --> 00:08:02.643
that they've installed,
the six button mouse is on there,

158
00:08:02.643 --> 00:08:05.760
it doesn't work the way
that it says it should.

159
00:08:05.760 --> 00:08:08.560
But, it was working fine
previously when you did that.

160
00:08:08.560 --> 00:08:11.390
Well, what you can is you can simply take,
let's say that mouse.

161
00:08:11.390 --> 00:08:13.600
I'm gonna make this represent that mouse.

162
00:08:13.600 --> 00:08:18.350
And then, I can go to Properties,
and I can select this Driver tab.

163
00:08:18.350 --> 00:08:22.030
And if I had just updated that
particular driver, what I could do,

164
00:08:22.030 --> 00:08:24.530
is I would select that Roll Back Driver.

165
00:08:24.530 --> 00:08:28.440
When you install a new driver over
the old one, it doesn't just erase it.

166
00:08:28.440 --> 00:08:30.240
It stores it in some secret location.

167
00:08:30.240 --> 00:08:31.329
Mike may actually know the exact path.

168
00:08:31.329 --> 00:08:33.338
>> [LAUGH]
>> Of where that secret location is.

169
00:08:33.338 --> 00:08:35.056
I know it's hidden, I know it's secret.

170
00:08:35.056 --> 00:08:36.810
I know it's not something I'm
not supposed to mess with.

171
00:08:36.810 --> 00:08:38.509
But Mike may actually
be going in their like,

172
00:08:38.509 --> 00:08:40.977
yeah I've actually messed with
this before, and that's fine.

173
00:08:40.977 --> 00:08:45.656
But it does, it stores it there just in
case the new driver that you actually

174
00:08:45.656 --> 00:08:48.390
installed, it kind of wigs out on you.

175
00:08:48.390 --> 00:08:49.640
And you can actually get that.

176
00:08:49.640 --> 00:08:50.480
It's like roll back.

177
00:08:50.480 --> 00:08:54.230
>> It's a very handy feature because
you can end up doing like Ronnie said,

178
00:08:54.230 --> 00:08:55.460
updating your driver.

179
00:08:55.460 --> 00:08:56.123
Things go bad.

180
00:08:56.123 --> 00:08:59.106
I want to go back to when
that device was working.

181
00:08:59.106 --> 00:09:01.850
What driver did I have before this?

182
00:09:01.850 --> 00:09:04.860
I didn't go and memorize all my driver
versions or anything like that.

183
00:09:04.860 --> 00:09:08.700
Or a user calls me up and says, hey,
I thought I was helping you out.

184
00:09:08.700 --> 00:09:12.230
I found this new driver for
my network adapter, I installed it.

185
00:09:12.230 --> 00:09:16.730
Turns out I got the wrong one, or
it's now broken something else.

186
00:09:16.730 --> 00:09:17.700
Can you fix my computer?

187
00:09:17.700 --> 00:09:20.520
Well, I don't know what driver they
had before that that actually worked.

188
00:09:20.520 --> 00:09:22.060
With this, it's easy.

189
00:09:22.060 --> 00:09:24.170
I just go in there and Roll Back Driver.

190
00:09:25.180 --> 00:09:28.520
If that driver's preventing
you from starting the machine,

191
00:09:28.520 --> 00:09:31.860
then you can go into Safe Mode and
do a Roll Back Driver.

192
00:09:31.860 --> 00:09:35.180
But it's not gonna be available until
you've at least updated the driver once.

193
00:09:35.180 --> 00:09:37.004
It also only remembers
the last one driver.

194
00:09:37.004 --> 00:09:41.511
So if you went from driver a,
to driver b, to driver c, to driver d,

195
00:09:41.511 --> 00:09:46.110
you can roll back to driver c, but
you're not gonna get back to b or a.

196
00:09:46.110 --> 00:09:49.662
It only remembers the last used driver,
but a very handy feature.

197
00:09:49.662 --> 00:09:52.498
>> Yeah it's a very handy
feature to roll that back, and

198
00:09:52.498 --> 00:09:55.850
then a lot of times right away,
you can try and test if it works.

episodes.description: In this episode Mike and Ronnie take a look at configuring accessibility and availability features in Windows 7. They show how to support such features such as Narrator, Magnifier and Sticky Keys. By exploring these features, a technician can troubleshoot accessibility options whether they should be enabled or not.
